## üöÄ NetScout‚ÄëPi v1.0 ‚Äî First Release Devblog

**NetScout‚ÄëPi** is a plugin‚Äëbased, web‚Äëdriven network diagnostics suite built specifically for the Raspberry‚ÄØPi. Inspired by headless, extensible monitoring tools, offering a complete solution for educational and experimental use ([github.com][1]).

---

### üìå Why NetScout‚ÄëPi?

The Raspberry‚ÄØPi makes a fantastic platform for learning networking fundamentals‚Äîbut configuring tools piecemeal (e.g. iperf3, tcpdump, traceroute) can be tedious and fragmented. NetScout‚ÄëPi bundles these core utilities into a single interface, enabling:

* Simultaneous diagnostic workflows
* Modular extensibility via plugins
* REST & WebSocket access
* Responsiveness on mobile and desktop devices

---

### üéØ Key Features in v1.0

* **Web Dashboard** with responsive UI showcasing real-time metrics
* **Live Interface Monitoring**: IP, MAC, packet counters, link status
* **Modular Plugin System**: Add new diagnostics via Go, Python, or Bash scripts
* Organized **Accordion Menu** by functionality
* **REST API** for automation, plus WebSocket real-time updates
* **External Plugin Support**, so users can tailor the tool to their environment

---

### üß∞ Core Tools & Plugins

#### Network Analysis

* **Interface Info**
* **Bandwidth Test** via iPerf3
* **QoS Simulation** (traffic control)
* **MTU Discovery** with ping sweeps
* **Packet Capture** via tcpdump

#### Connectivity

* **Ping** and **Traceroute**

#### Discovery

* **Port Scanner**, **LAN Device Discovery**, **Wi‚ÄëFi Scanner**

#### DNS

* **DNS Lookup**, **Propagation Checker**, **Reverse Lookup**

#### Security

* **SSL/TLS Checker**

---

### ‚öôÔ∏è How to Build & Run

1. **Clone & build** with Go¬†1.16+

   ```bash
   git clone https://github.com/raf181/NetScout-Pi.git
   cd NetScout-Pi
   go build
   ```

   > *Tip for Pi Zero 2W users*: add `CGO_ENABLED=0` if you encounter build issues.

2. **Run** locally:

   ```bash
   ./netscout-pi --port=8080
   ```

3. **Visit** `http://<pi-ip>:8080` from any browser.

4. **Optional: run as a service** with a systemd unit for auto startup.

---

### üß© Plugin System Highlights

Projects are only as powerful as their plugins. Key features include:

* **Metadata-driven**: each plugin has a `plugin.json` for name, category, parameters
* **Decoupled execution**: Go/Cli/persistent processes
* **Categorization**: easy navigation via accordion UI
* **API access**: `GET /api/plugins`, `POST /api/plugins/<id>/run`

Example:

```bash
curl -X POST http://<pi-ip>:8080/api/plugins/ping/run \
     -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
     -d '{"host":"example.com","count":4}'
```

Returns structured JSON with result details.

---

### ‚ö° Web & Real-Time Features

* **RESTful endpoints** for all tools
* **WebSockets** providing continuous updates (e.g., real-time network stats)
* **Mobile-first design** in the user interface

---

### üõ† Known Issues & Roadmap

**Warning: v1.0 is beta-grade. Not production-ready.**

* Some plugins (like QoS or MTU tester) need better error handling and permissions
* Packet capture may need sudo or root access
* **Next milestones**:

  * Authentication & ACLs
  * Secure HTTPS support
  * Expanded plugin library (SSL cert, DNS, SNMP)
  * Enhanced UX: plugin search, dynamic config
  * Metrics logging+visualizations

---

### üõ° Security & Performance

* No auth or TLS in v1.0 ‚Äî please use it only in trusted/enclosed environments
* Plugin execution is synchronous and blocking; expect delays with long-running tools
* Future support planned for asynchronous, rate-limited operations

---

### üßë‚Äçüéì Contribute & Develop

Want to help?

1. **Fork** the repo
2. Create a feature branch
3. **Craft plugins** following `app/plugins/DEVELOPMENT.md`
4. Submit a **PR** ‚Äî documentation, code clarity, tests much appreciated

---

### üìÑ License & Acknowledgments

Licensed under MIT. Thanks to:

* Go ecosystem for networking libraries
* Raspberry Pi foundation for enabling hardware flexibility
* Early testers and contributors

---

### üéâ Closing

NetScout‚ÄëPi v1.0 delivers a foundational network diagnostics platform tailored for Raspberry‚ÄØPi enthusiasts. Its modular architecture invites experimentation‚Äîperfect for learning or light troubleshooting. Though still early stage, it offers a unified experience across diagnostics, monitoring, and API automation.

Check it out on GitHub, test it out on your Pi, and let‚Äôs build the next generation of plugins together!

Well, this is the first devlog (*8 hours in*), and it very well may be the only devlog I post, but I'd still like to talk a bit about the process and the decisions that I made along the way. 

Why this project? Well, I was looking around my unfinished projects directory when I came across this project from a couple years ago. I wanted to give it a shot at finishing it, or at least polishing it up a bit. 

The general idea of how this program works is a bit counterintuitive. While most fire simulations represent heat as things that rise, and so pixels tend to set pixels higher than them. This simulation does the reverse. Each pixel looks at pixels below it in order to determine its heat value. This also has the unintended (but not unwelcome) side effect of making the bottom row of pixels always keep its heat value, as they do not have pixels below them to look up their new heat values, so the "ground" is "flammable". The X coordinate is also warped by a random amount, plus some scrolling perlin noise for added variety with coherence. The "sparks" at the tops of the flames are emergent behavior, there is no part of the code that intentionally creates those.

Why Python? Well, it's what I know best. Additionally, I'd recently discovered [Taichi](https://docs.taichi-lang.org/), a domain specific, high performance, parallel language that is embedded within, and uses the semantics of, Python. Taichi allows me to run the fire simulation at a solid 60fps, and I've gotten it to run at 120 FPS at 1440x960 before being bottlenecked. At 640x480, it runs at a blazing (ha) fast 500 fps. None of these are precise benchmarks, and YMMV.

I use PySide6 for the GUI, as my machine uses Plasma for the Desktop Environment, so it just made sense to write something for QT. Also, I know the library reasonably well. 
While this project is not intended to be a realistic fire simulation, it does have an excellent stylized fire look to it.

Devlog 0: Introduction

Hey! Welcome to this project's first devlog! Well actually, this really isn't a 'devlog' more than it's a previously on segment, but it's the thought that counts. So first things first: This is a preexisting project (by like a monthish). As such, there's already a ton of progress made to it from before I joined this summer codeathon thing. So let me catch you up:

Essentially, this is a hobby project that I'm turning into a library for a friend. You see, over the years, my friend has made a GIANT quotebook that contains a bunch of out-of-context quotes that they made throughout their school life. As a fun end-of-year activity, they asked me to make a program that automatically converts quotes in said quotebook into Kahoot questions that have them guess who made each quote. Sound easy, right? Well, not quite. 

You see, while Kahoot has an API, their API is for **playing** Kahoots, not making them. And even if they DID have an API for my exact use case (they don't), their API is only for "certain highest-tier [Kahoot] plans." and requires me to "reach out to [my] customer success manager" for access. I looked, and their highest plan is their Enterprise plan for a kajillion dollars. Probably should have figured when I found it under their enterprise support...

But I wasn't out of luck yet. While Kahoot doesn't have an API for making Kahoots, they do have manual ways for creating Kahoots. That means that I could make a web scraper to act like a human and "manually" create a Kahoot with some programmed instructions. Now armed with a plan of action, I threw together a program that used Selenium Base (a Python-based web scraper library) to generate a Kahoot based on information given to it in a dictionary. But after I made it, I realized that this might be a tool that people could find useful to use. And so, I decided to take the Kahoot bot I made and transform it into a library someone could pip install, do a bit of setup, and use on their own devices. 

"But Jediweirdo," I hear you ask, "aren't you basically done with this project?" Hahahahahahahaha, no. While I started making this a library before joining this program, I'm nowhere near done. If I'm being kind, I'm like 20% or 30% through this process. I figured out how I want people to interact with the library and created the endpoints that users can use to access the library's internal code, but it flat out doesn't work due to problems I'm facing with idiot-proofing the soon-to-be-library. Day 1: CarbonIQ - First Seeds Planted
Today was day one for CarbonIQ, and it's already feeling like a solid start. I got the project initialized with Next.js (TypeScript), which is my go-to for a robust frontend, and integrated Tailwind CSS without a hitch. Clean styling from the get-go is always a win.

I immediately set up a logical folder structure: components/, sections/, data/, and other essentials. This disciplined approach will definitely help with scalability down the line.

The first visual piece is a Hero section that's high-contrast and centered, welcoming users with bold text about tracking India's internet carbon emissions. Below that, I added placeholder category tabs like "Streaming" and "AI"‚Äîthe idea is to make these interactive for live impact tracking.

Finally, I created a static multipliers.json file with some fake data (e.g., 0.2g CO‚ÇÇ per Google search). This will be key for future calculations. No backend yet, but laying this foundation feels like planting the first seed for something big. üå±

# Development Log - My Code Life

## Project Overview
A minimal, dark, animated dashboard designed to help users live by three powerful life rules, featuring an AI advisor and tools for managing contacts, notes, and daily reflections.

## Major Features Implemented

### 1. Authentication System
- **Supabase Integration**: Set up authentication with Supabase backend
- **Login/Logout Flow**: Secure user authentication with session management
- **Protected Routes**: Route protection for authenticated users only

### 2. Dashboard & Navigation
- **Main Dashboard**: Central hub with animated, dark theme interface
- **Sidebar Navigation**: Clean navigation between different sections
- **Responsive Design**: Mobile-first responsive layout using TailwindCSS

### 3. Contacts Management System
- **CRUD Operations**: Full create, read, update, delete functionality for contacts
- **Contact Details**: Store name, email, phone, relationship, notes, and tags
- **Search & Filter**: Search contacts by name, filter by relationship type
- **Import/Export**: JSON import/export functionality for contact backup
- **Family Access Integration**: Toggle to enable family portal access for contacts

### 4. Notes Management
- **Note Creation**: Rich text note creation with categories
- **Organization**: Categorize notes (personal, work, ideas, etc.)
- **Search Functionality**: Search through notes by title and content
- **Timestamps**: Automatic creation and update timestamps

### 5. AI Advisor (Gemini Integration)
- **Life Rules Guidance**: AI advisor based on three core life principles
- **Chat Interface**: Interactive chat with the AI advisor
- **Contextual Advice**: Personalized guidance based on user queries

### 6. Family Portal System
- **Family Login Page**: Separate authentication for family members
- **Family Registration**: Registration system for new family members
- **Family Profiles**: Individual profiles for each family member
- **Status Management**: Online/offline status tracking for family members
- **Call Requests**: Schedule and manage family video call requests

### 7. Database Architecture
- **Supabase Tables**: 
  - `contacts` - Contact information storage
  - `notes` - Notes and reflections storage
  - `family_members` - Family member profiles
  - `family_member_status` - Family member status tracking
  - `call_requests` - Family call scheduling
- **Row Level Security**: Implemented RLS policies for data protection
- **Timestamps**: Automatic timestamp management with triggers

### 8. UI/UX Components
- **Shadcn/UI Components**: Modern, accessible UI component library
- **Dark Theme**: Consistent dark theme throughout the application
- **Animations**: Smooth transitions and hover effects
- **Loading States**: Proper loading indicators for async operations
- **Error Handling**: User-friendly error messages and validation

### 9. Recent Integration Work
- **Contact-Family Bridge**: Connected existing contacts system with family portal
- **Registration Flow**: Seamless flow from contact invitation to family registration
- **Database Schema Updates**: Added family access fields to contacts table
- **Authentication Updates**: Enhanced authentication to support hashed passwords
- **RLS Policy Fixes**: Resolved row-level security issues for family member registration

## Technical Stack
- **Frontend**: React 18 with TypeScript
- **Build Tool**: Vite
- **Styling**: TailwindCSS
- **UI Components**: Shadcn/UI
- **Backend**: Supabase (Database, Auth, Storage)
- **AI**: Google Gemini API
- **Routing**: React Router
- **State Management**: React hooks (useState, useEffect)

## Current Status
- ‚úÖ Core dashboard functionality complete
- ‚úÖ Contacts management fully implemented
- ‚úÖ Notes system operational
- ‚úÖ AI advisor integrated and working
- ‚úÖ Family portal authentication system complete
- ‚úÖ Family registration flow implemented
- ‚úÖ Database schema properly configured
- ‚úÖ Contact-family integration complete
- üîß Currently resolving RLS policy issues for family member registration

## Next Steps
1. Test family member registration flow end-to-end
2. Implement family member profile editing
3. Add family chat/messaging functionality
4. Enhance AI advisor with more contextual awareness
5. Add notification system for family interactions
6. Implement data export/backup features
7. Add analytics and usage tracking

## Known Issues
- RLS policies needed adjustment for family member registration (recently fixed)
- Some mobile responsiveness improvements needed
- Family member profile pictures upload functionality pending

# Aurelis 1.0.0 

**Release Date:** June 17, 2025  
**Version:** 1.0.0

## Overview

We're thrilled to announce the official release of Aurelis 1.0.0, an enterprise-grade AI-powered code assistant exclusively powered by GitHub Models via Azure AI Inference. This release marks a significant milestone in bringing AI-assisted development to enterprise teams with a focus on security, reliability, and advanced code intelligence.

## Key Features

### Enterprise-Grade AI Integration

- **GitHub Models Integration**: Full support for Codestral-2501, GPT-4o, GPT-4o-mini, Cohere Command-R/R+, Meta Llama 3.1, and Mistral models via Azure AI Inference
- **Unified Authentication**: Single GitHub token authentication for all model access
- **Intelligent Model Routing**: Automatic model selection based on task type, complexity, and performance metrics
- **Advanced Fallback Logic**: Enterprise-grade error handling with circuit breaker patterns for reliable service operation
- **Azure AI Inference Integration**: Production-ready API connections with enterprise security and reliability

### Code Intelligence

- **Real-time Code Analysis**: Comprehensive static analysis with syntax, performance, security, and style verification
- **AI-Powered Code Generation**: Convert natural language descriptions to production-ready, typed Python code
- **Intelligent Refactoring**: Automated code optimization and modernization suggestions
- **Documentation Generation**: Comprehensive docstrings and technical documentation with consistent style
- **Context-Aware Processing**: Smart context chunking for optimal model utilization and handling large codebases

### Development Workflow

- **CLI Interface**: Comprehensive command-line interface with intuitive subcommands
- **Interactive Shell**: Rich REPL environment with auto-completion, syntax highlighting, and conversation history
- **Session Management**: Persistent contexts and conversation tracking across development sessions
- **Tool Integration**: Pre-built integrations with common developer tools and workflows
- **Project Analysis**: Codebase-wide insights and recommendations

### Security & Architecture

- **Enterprise Security**: Secure token management, encryption, and comprehensive audit logging
- **Performance Optimization**: Response caching, concurrent processing, and adaptive resource allocation
- **Modular Architecture**: Clean separation of concerns with microservices-inspired design
- **Comprehensive Monitoring**: Health checks, performance metrics, and detailed logging
- **Enterprise Deployment**: Support for containerized deployment with Docker and Kubernetes

## Installation

### PyPI Installation

```bash
pip install aurelisai
```

### From Source

```bash
git clone https://github.com/kanopusdev/aurelis.git
cd aurelis
pip install -e .
```

## Quick Start

```bash
# Initialize Aurelis with your GitHub token
aurelis config init --github-token YOUR_GITHUB_TOKEN

# Analyze code in the current directory
aurelis analyze ./

# Generate code from a description
aurelis generate "Create a function that calculates Fibonacci numbers with memoization"

# Start the interactive shell
aurelis shell
```

## System Requirements

- **Python**: 3.10 or higher
- **Operating Systems**: Windows, macOS, Linux
- **RAM**: 4GB minimum, 8GB recommended
- **Disk Space**: 500MB minimum
- **Network**: Reliable internet connection for API access
- **Authorization**: GitHub personal access token with appropriate scopes

## Breaking Changes

As this is the initial 1.0.0 release, there are no breaking changes from previous versions.

## Known Issues

- Large codebase analysis (>50k LOC) may experience timeouts on models with smaller context windows
- Interactive shell has limited rendering support in Windows Command Prompt (use PowerShell or Windows Terminal for best experience)
- VS Code extension integration is currently in beta status

## Future Development

Upcoming features planned for the next releases:

- **IDE Integrations**: Deeper integration with VS Code, JetBrains IDEs
- **Advanced Code Transformation**: More sophisticated refactoring and migration capabilities
- **Team Collaboration**: Shared contexts and collaboration features
- **Additional Models**: Support for more language models as they become available
- **Extended Language Support**: Enhanced capabilities for JavaScript/TypeScript, Go, Rust, and Java

## Feedback & Support

We welcome your feedback and contributions:

- **GitHub Issues**: [github.com/kanopusdev/aurelis/issues](https://github.com/kanopusdev/aurelis/issues)
- **Documentation**: [aurelis.kanopus.org](https://aurelis.kanopus.org)
- **Email**: [support@kanopus.org](mailto:support@kanopus.org)

## Acknowledgements

Aurelis is developed by the Kanopus team, with special thanks to our contributors, early adopters, and the open-source community. This project would not be possible without the groundbreaking work by GitHub on AI models for code.

## License

Aurelis is released under the MIT License. See the LICENSE file for details.

## üß† Implementing ARP in NetScout‚ÄëPi is Driving Me Crazy

I dove into implementing basic ARP support for NetScout‚ÄëPi‚Äîthinking it'd be straightforward‚Äîbut quickly realized there‚Äôs nothing "basic" about ARP at the raw-packet level


### ARP: A Layer 2 Protocol with Hidden Complexities

ARP isn‚Äôt just sending and receiving packets‚Äîit operates at Ethernet frame level (`AF_PACKET`, raw sockets, Linux capabilities), which means:

üîπ You need `CAP_NET_RAW` or root access just to send WIRE-LAYER frames
üîπ You must handle packet marshaling, broadcast vs unicast, timeouts, retries‚Ä¶ following RFC‚ÄØ826 properly


### Ghosts & Race Conditions: ARP Behaves Weirdly

üîπ Gratuitous ARP or unsolicited replies can overwrite entries unexpectedly
üîπ My simple "send request, wait reply" loop gets confused when duplicates or stray frames arrive
üîπ ARP cache entries expire automatically (TTL, staleness), complicating logic‚Äîhow often do I refresh before stale data?
üîπ On busy LANs, ARP replies might arrive piggybacked or delayed‚Äîsocket deadlines, duplicate requests and broadcasts add chaos


### Why It‚Äôs Mentally Taxing

üîπ Debugging on a Pi means juggling `tcpdump`, goroutines, raw sockets, and weird kernel behavior
üîπ Getting the packet framing wrong (padding, EtherType) nukes everything silently
üîπ Fuzzing edge cases: spoofed replies, broadcast storms, negative caches, and ARP poisoning vulnerabilities


### üò° My Sanity Checkpoints

1 Switched to using `mdlayher/arp` library to validate my packet structure 
2 Logged every ARP transaction, including unsolicited ones, and introduced cooldowns to avoid storms
3 Ensured raw socket privileges and deadlines are correctly managed each goroutine

---

### TL;DR ü§Ø

Implementing ARP isn‚Äôt ‚Äúsimple‚Äù‚Äîit‚Äôs a layer-2 tangle of raw sockets, packet framing, broadcast logic, TTL, and race conditions After days of sporadic failures, libraries and careful socket handling were my sanity savers Hats off to those who deal with ARP daily‚Äîit‚Äôs easy to underestimate how tricky it can get!

üöÄ Build NetScout‚ÄëPi Together: Community Plugin Drive

I‚Äôm looking to grow NetScout‚ÄëPi into a full-featured network diagnostics platform‚Äîand I need your help!

I‚Äôve seen impressive community-driven work like CheckDaWeb by Bedlessdeus, which showcases the power of user-built plugins. Now I want to bring that spirit here‚Äîcreating custom plugins developed and shared by you, the community.

What I‚Äôm Looking For
   üîπ New network tools: monitoring, scanning, visualizing, alerting‚Ä¶ any diagnostic functionality you‚Äôre passionate about.

   üîπ Ready-to-go formats: Go, Python, Bash scripts‚Äîif you can wrap it into our plugin system, let‚Äôs integrate it.

   üîπ Examples to get started: Realtime traffic visualizers, Custom QoS benchmarks, Enhanced DNS/security checks

Why Join In?
   üîπ Showcase your plugin to all NetScout‚ÄëPi users
   üîπ Improve your coding skills & contribute to open source
   üîπ Shape a versatile, community-defined toolkit

How to Get Involved
1. Fork the repo
2. Add a plugin in app/plugins/, following the development guide
3. Submit a Pull Request‚Äîinclude docs and tests
4. Let‚Äôs iterate together!

Been wrestling with the frequency detection, The original autocorrelation algorithm kept getting fooled by harmonics and giving me wildly inconsistent readings when measuring belt tension. When you pluck a printer belt it creates this complex signal with overtones, and the algorithm would latch onto the stronger harmonics instead of the actual fundamental frequency I needed.

Added an FFT-based algorithm as an alternative that cuts through the harmonic confusion much better. It has more jumps in the readings, but it's way more reliable at finding the true fundamental frequency. Now users can switch between both algorithms depending on what works better for their setup.

Timed-Type Devlog - Enhanced Timed Typing Automation  
Overview  
This devlog describes the development journey of TypeRiser, a desktop application for automating text input into any program with customizable timing and targeting options. Building on the original Timed Typer, this version brings notable improvements in usability, precision, and flexibility. It uses Python, Tkinter, PyAutoGUI, and optional dependencies like OpenCV, pystray, and pynput.  
Development Milestones  
Initial Foundation (Original Timed Typer)  

Core Functionality: I created a Tkinter-based GUI for typing text into any application at controlled speeds (30-2000 CPM), using PyAutoGUI for automation.  
Features:  
- Debug mode for console output.  
- Target selection: current cursor, screen center, or click-based.  
- Failsafe mechanism (move mouse to top-left corner to stop).  
- Test mode to type "Hello" for verification.  
- Customizable delay (0-60 seconds).  

Challenges:  
- Click detection was basic, requiring users to wait out the full timeout.  
- Speed was defined in CPM, limiting flexibility for different use cases.  
- No support for repeated typing or advanced targeting.  

Enhancements in TypeRiser  

New Features:  
- Time-Based Input: I replaced CPM with total time input (seconds, minutes, hours) for more intuitive control over typing duration.  
- Repeat Functionality: I added repeat count (1-100) and pause between repeats (0-60 seconds) for automated, multi-pass typing.  
- Text Import: I enabled importing text from .txt files to streamline input of large text blocks.  
- Persistent Click Target: I implemented a saved click position that stays until reset, improving efficiency for repeated typing tasks at the same location.  
- Image-Based Targeting: I integrated OpenCV (cv2) to locate targets through screenshot matching (confidence level 0.8), with a fallback if opencv-python is not available.  
- System Tray Integration: I added an optional system tray icon using pystray and PIL for minimizing the app and quick access (show/hide, exit).  
- Global Hotkey: I introduced a Ctrl+Shift+S hotkey using keyboard to stop typing instantly, working alongside the PyAutoGUI failsafe.  
- Improved Click Detection: I replaced basic click detection with pynput.mouse for reliable, first-click capture within a 5-second window, ignoring subsequent clicks.  

UI Improvements:  
- Added a combobox for time unit selection (seconds, minutes, hours).  
- Introduced a status label for the click target position, updating dynamically when set or reset.  
- Enhanced instructions to include hotkey and persistent click target details.  

Technical Improvements:  
- Improved error handling for file imports, input validation, and OpenCV operations.  
- Ensured thread-safe operations for typing, click detection, and tray icon management.  
- Added dynamic dependency checks for opencv-python, pystray, and PIL to provide graceful failure if unavailable.  
- Optimized the typing process with pyautogui.moveTo before clicking for better accuracy.  

Challenges Overcome  

Click Detection: The original wait-for-click logic often missed clicks or required full timeout. Using pynput.mouse ensured reliable, single-click capture.  
Image Targeting: Integrating OpenCV required addressing cases where the library or target image was unavailable, providing clear user feedback through status updates.  
System Tray: I maintained functionality without dependencies by making pystray and PIL optional and adding fallback messages.  
Hotkey Management: Registering and removing the Ctrl+Shift+S hotkey cleanly on app exit was crucial to prevent resource leaks.  
Time-Based Logic: Converting from CPM to total time meant recalculating typing intervals dynamically to ensure smooth pacing across different text lengths.  

Future Improvements  

- Advanced Image Targeting: Support for multiple image targets or region-based matching for more complex automation tasks.  
- Config Presets: Allow saving and loading configurations (text, time, target, etc.) for recurring tasks.  
- Cross-Platform Testing: Validate compatibility on macOS and Linux, addressing any PyAutoGUI quirks.  
- Accessibility Features: Add keyboard navigation and screen reader support for the Tkinter UI.  
- Performance Optimization: Reduce CPU usage during long typing sessions with large repeat counts.  

Conclusion  
Timed-Type marks a significant update of the original Timed Typer, providing better flexibility, precision, and ease of use. The addition of time-based control, persistent click targets, image-based targeting, system tray support, and global hotkeys makes it a powerful tool for those interested in automation, developers, and users focused on accessibility. The project continues to develop, with plans for more refinements and new features.  
Last Updated: June 18, 2025

Having a lot of fun putting concrete and testable *STRONG* Rust types on the Somnia Standard REST API. Turns out their docs are wildly out of date, have so many duplicate fields its actually funny, and encode their numbers in three separate formats, including base 10 radix strings, standard JSON numbers, scientific notation JSON (for larger numbers, some special handling of these was necessary), f64 floating point numbers, u128 monotonic UNIX timestamps, and the list probably goes on as I flesh out my integration. Very glad I've added testing for each endpoint!
API docs: https://learn.standardweb3.com/apps/spot/for-developers/rest-api#get-api-tradehistory-address-pagesize-page

More CI work!
I added more checks to CI to ensure less problems with the code:
1. Check if `cargo doc` returns any errors
2. Check if code is formatted properly (`cargo fmt`)
3. Audit for security vulnerabilities (`cargo audit`)
4. Check for license mismatches etc. (`cargo deny`)

üõ†Ô∏è GhostShell ‚Äî Day 2 Devlog

Today was all about building persistence and making logs useful.

‚úÖ Completed:
- Created `logger.py` with support for both `.jsonl` and SQLite.
- Integrated an optional `--debug` flag to print log snapshots in color using `rich`.
- Designed and implemented `log_db.py`:
  - Automatically creates `logs.db` and the `connections` table.
  - Inserts each connection with geo-IP metadata (`country`, `ISP`, etc.).
- Added fallback handling for connections missing location data.
- Ensured clean and readable log format with timestamps and visual polish.
- Built a `logs_viewer.py` CLI tool:
  - Can search logs by IP substring or country code.
  - Displays results in a beautiful rich-powered table.
  - Can filter by date (`--date` argument) and limit result count (`--limit`).

üìÇ Files added/updated:
- `ghostshell/logger.py`
- `ghostshell/log_db.py`
- `ghostshell/logs_viewer.py`
- `logs/logs.db` (generated automatically)

üìå Notes:
- The SQLite log format ensures efficient querying and long-term storage.
- Modular design makes it easy to expand filters and add a TUI/GUI viewer later.

Next up (Day 3): Potential features like suspicious activity detection, automatic scanning, live monitoring, and geo-IP visualizations.

üîí GhostShell is slowly taking form ‚Äî a future-ready security observability tool for your terminal.

I finally managed to fix the length correction on received Wi-Fi frames once and for all. Since the ESP32 Wi-Fi peripheral uses DMA to transfer the received frames into memory, the length of the frames is always aligned to 4 bytes, due to a quirk of the DMA engine. Calculating the correct length was pretty tedious, since my first approach appeared to work, but didn't. Finally, it started working yesterday. The new code is in the attached screenshot.

üòµ Wi‚ÄëFi Device Locator: 20 Hours Down the Rabbit Hole‚Ä¶ Thanks ADHD
I spent 20 straight hours obsessively building a Wi‚ÄëFi device locator plugin for NetScout‚ÄëPi‚Äîhoping to use signal strength and triangulation to find devices via the Pi's Wi‚ÄëFi NIC. What I got instead was a total headache:

üì° Raw monitor‚Äëmode scans are unreliable and require fiddling with airodump-ng, raw sockets, and permissions.

üîÑ Signal strength doesn‚Äôt map cleanly to distance indoors: walls, interference, random decay.

üß© My code spiraled into complicated triangulation and filtering logic that still feels inaccurate.

My ADHD hyperfixation kicked in, locking me into this tangent that seemed so promising‚Äîuntil I hit logs, packet parsing, and false positives that made me mad. I just wanted a simple "point & locate", but ended up in a tangled mess of CSV parsing, Go concurrency, and endless retries.

Oh‚Äîand this all started because I was trying to build a custom Go library to interact with ARP packets‚Ä¶ which somehow led me here. Great decisions, as always.

TL;DR
Should I ditch this feature?
Yes and no‚Äîit's definitely educational, but maybe I need to accept some limitations or approach it differently later.

Anyone else fallen down a wireless‚Äëlocator rabbit hole? üòÖ

God, I love and hate the ADHD hyperfocus trap‚Äîit's like willingly jumping into a pit, then angrily digging deeper because "I've already started." üôÉ

I built a simple desktop app using Python that lets you select an MP4 video, convert it to MP3, and play both video and audio. The interface is built with Tkinter and is easy to use.

For audio conversion, I used MoviePy to extract the audio from the video file. Video playback is done with OpenCV, and audio is handled by Pygame. I combined them with threading so that both can run at the same time without freezing the app.

The app has buttons to select a file, convert it, play the video with sound, play audio only, and stop everything. I also used PIL to convert video frames to images that Tkinter can display.

One tricky part was keeping the video and audio synced, but using a separate thread for video helped. The GUI stays responsive even while playing.

It works well for basic use, but I plan to add features like pause, seek, or format support later. This project was fun to build and taught me a lot about handling media in Python.

Updated the game with a new gamemode, Turtle Tug, a functional Turtle Tug-of-War game with some minor bugs.

I have made significant progress and have successfully implemented a variety of complex features in my game:

Core Jump & Run Mechanics
I‚Äôve implemented basic platformer movement: horizontal control, gravity, and jumping. These form the foundation of the gameplay.

Procedural World Generation
Platforms: I generate platforms of arbitrary widths, heights, and gaps by using Perlin Noise, so that each map is a new experience.
Walls: Random vertical wall sections are inserted, offering surfaces for sophisticated movement maneuvers.

Improved Player Skills
Wall Run: As they fall and lean against a wall, the player decelerates, enabling wall-interaction strategies.
Wall Jump: I can push off walls while wall-running to reach higher areas, which adds more depth to the platforming.
Mouse Aiming & Shooting: Left-click can be used as a laser weapon, shooting directly at mouse position.

Varied Enemy Types

Standard Enemies: Stationary blocks that are affected by gravity.

Flying Enemies: Travel laterally across the screen.

Rolling Enemies: Patrol certain platforms.

Jumping Enemies: Periodically leap off their platforms.

Dynamic Difficulty Scaling
As the score goes up, it automatically tweaks factors like enemy speed and spawn rate. It ensures that difficulty remains manageable and fun.

Interactive Menu System
A prominent main menu with choices such as "START GAME," "HOW TO PLAY," "GAME DETAILS," and "QUIT"

Visual Feedback: Buttons show highlight on hover and a brief flash on click.

Audio Feedback: Clicking a button triggers distinct procedural tones.

Procedural Music
There is a basic randomized melody in a chiptune style during gameplay, which cycles on each newly created world.

In-Game Art Customization
By pressing the C key, I can cycle through different preset color themes for the player, platforms, walls, and enemies. This allows me to change the art style in real time while playing.

‚ÄúRegenerate World in Place‚Äù (R Key)
This primary characteristic makes it possible for me to create a new world instantly around me‚Äîmy current location‚Äîwithout losing my score or health. It makes exploration seamless without having to restart.

Game Details Screen
Another screen displays the active world's generation seed and color mapping for the procedural art.

HUD
A heads-up display shows my current score and health.

Dev Log ‚Äì MindPilot ‚Äì 2025.06.18
Today, significant progress was made on the backend of the MindPilot project. I successfully set up a FastAPI server that handles API requests for AI-powered topic explanations. I integrated the Cohere API using their Command R+ model to generate clear, simple explanations suitable for learners.
Key tasks completed:
Configured environment variables securely with a .env file for API key management.
Built the /api/explain POST endpoint that receives a topic and returns an AI-generated explanation.
Ensured proper CORS middleware settings to allow smooth communication with the React frontend running on localhost.
Tested the backend thoroughly using curl, Postman, and FastAPI‚Äôs interactive docs, confirming error-free responses.
Resolved common errors related to API key handling and Cohere client usage, improving the stability of the backend.
Next steps:
Connect the backend with the React frontend to create a seamless user experience.
Expand the AI capabilities by adding new features such as personalized progress tracking.
Begin planning for additional languages and multi-subject support.
Overall, today laid a solid foundation for the core AI functionality of MindPilot and set up a stable backend infrastructure for future development.

Devlog ‚Äî Catch Blocks Ultimate
I made Catch Blocks Ultimate using Python and Pygame. It‚Äôs a simple but fun game where you move a paddle to catch falling blocks. Each block does something different ‚Äî some give points, some give you extra lives, some give shields, and others slow down the blocks for a bit.

I added a shop where you can spend coins to upgrade your shield, slow-motion power-up, or add turrets that automatically shoot blocks for you. The turrets help keep the game challenging but also more fun.

The game has different difficulty levels and a ‚ÄúCrazy Mode‚Äù where you get all the upgrades and tons of lives ‚Äî just for when you want to mess around.

I also put in a cool animated starry background to make the visuals nicer and added screens for starting the game, showing instructions, and ending the game.

It was a great way to practice working with game states, handling input, drawing graphics, and making the gameplay smooth. I‚Äôm pretty happy with how it turned out and want to keep improving it with more features and polish.

Assignme is a  web app built to simplify assignment processing and custom font generation. It offers a clean UI, modular codebase, and smooth API integration to help users upload, customize, and process assignments effortlessly.

Assignment API for processing uploaded content
Font API for real-time font creation

In this long ahh session I managed to get the template system working. Essentially, you can create templates for certain kinds of problems (ex: permutations, binary search, etc) using the command `cp-cli template --make name.ext --alias alias` the template subcommand has other arguments for useful things such as the `--make` command which allows you to make a template with the alias argument. So a binary search template command would look like:

`cp-cli template --make binarySearch.cpp --alias binarySearch`

and to use this template, simply use the command `cp-cli template --use alias --filename name.ext`. The --use flag followed by `alias` just refers to the alias created in the command before and the `--filename` tag allows you to use that template in a predefine path in the config command

I've had to do a multitude of things in the last 2.5 hours of working. First off all, the LLaVA source code that I'm using is for some reason bugged on my computer and I had to find the right places to debug within the hundreds of files and hundred-thousands of lines of code. Other than that, apparently the source code only allows NVIDIA GPU-based running, and I have an Intel GPU so I had to edit the source code such that it went from supporting GPU to CPU. After all that, I'm currently letting it run and it's run for a while with no errors so far so fingers crossed. If this doesn't work, I may need to switch to some kind of hard-code based SIVRAJ instead of an AI-based one. Or I could try and make my own model, which honestly could be the play. I need to go to sleep now so that's a problem for tomorrow.

Devlog #1: My Dev Toolbox ‚Äî Chaos Edition

Alright folks, here‚Äôs the deal ‚Äî I‚Äôm building this dev toolbox because honestly, I got tired of juggling a million apps just to get stuff done. So now I‚Äôm juggling one app that‚Äôs still figuring out if it wants to work or just crash dramatically. Spoiler: sometimes it chooses chaos.

Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs cooking:
üü¢ Code snippets ‚Äî color-coded like a rainbow threw up on my keyboard. You can save ‚Äôem, edit ‚Äôem, and maybe even understand them later.
üü¢ Terminal commands ‚Äî copy ‚Äôem, run ‚Äôem, feel like a hacker without opening a terminal. Warning: no cool hacker music included.
üü¢ Zipper ‚Äî unzip anything. Windows, macOS, Linux ‚Äî this bad boy doesn‚Äôt discriminate. (It says it zipped/unzipped your files, but don‚Äôt trust it too much ‚Äî it‚Äôs lying to you.)

Yeah, the whole UI‚Äôs a little bugged right now ‚Äî buttons that sometimes don‚Äôt do what they‚Äôre supposed to, messages acting like soap opera drama queens‚Ä¶ but hey, that‚Äôs part of the fun, right?

Yes, it breaks. Yes, I scream at my code daily. But hey, if building your own toolbox was easy, everyone would do it, right? This is the real dev life ‚Äî bugs, caffeine, and the eternal hope that tomorrow‚Äôs build won‚Äôt crash on launch.

If you wanna watch this dumpster fire grow into something useful, stick around. Feedback, jokes, and memes highly encouraged.

DEMO UP, try it!
I made a quick website. Mostly AI-generated, as you'll probably notice.

Why? Originally, you just had to SSH into the terminal(you still can: "ssh quinver.dev -p 2222"), no config needed. But not everyone knows how to use SSH or even dares to open a terminal. So I slapped it onto a web page instead.

Now it's accessible to anyone, no terminal knowledge required(At least to connect).

Try it out and let me know what you think:

 -  Was it clear how the commands work?

 - Did anything feel off or glitchy?

 - Any spelling mistakes or weird duplication?

Feedback‚Äôs welcome, it helps polish things up.

# Aoede Enterprise AI No-Code Agent - Development Log

**Total Development Time: 10 hours, 16 minutes, 35 seconds**

---

## Project Overview
Built a complete enterprise-grade AI no-code platform from scratch using Python, FastAPI, HTML, Tailwind CSS, and vanilla JavaScript. The application integrates with GitHub's AI models (Azure AI Inference SDK) and provides intelligent code generation, testing, and validation capabilities.

---

## Timeline & Achievements

### Hour 1-2: Foundation & Architecture
- Set up FastAPI application with proper project structure
- Implemented core configuration with Pydantic settings
- Created database models using SQLAlchemy (PostgreSQL + SQLite fallback)
- Established security middleware with CORS, rate limiting, and input validation

### Hour 2-4: AI Integration & Core Services
- Integrated Azure AI Inference SDK with 4 GitHub models:
  - `mistral-ai/Codestral-2501` (Code Generation)
  - `openai/gpt-4.1` (General Purpose)
  - `openai/gpt-4o` (Advanced Reasoning)
  - `cohere/cohere-command-a` (Text Processing)
- Built intelligent chunking system for 4K token limitations
- Implemented model health checking and automatic failover
- Created comprehensive error handling and retry mechanisms

### Hour 4-6: API Development & Business Logic
- Developed complete REST API with 15+ endpoints
- Built code generation service with multi-language support
- Implemented testing and validation service with iterative error fixing
- Added real-time WebSocket communication for live updates
- Created enterprise-grade logging and monitoring

### Hour 6-8: Frontend Development
- Designed modern, responsive UI with Tailwind CSS
- Built interactive dashboard with animated statistics
- Created code generation interface with syntax highlighting
- Implemented testing lab with real-time feedback
- Added AI model management and monitoring sections

### Hour 8-9: DevOps & Production Ready
- Created Docker containerization with multi-stage builds
- Built Kubernetes deployment manifests
- Implemented CI/CD pipeline with GitHub Actions
- Added comprehensive test suite with pytest
- Created deployment scripts and environment management

### Hour 9-10: Enhancement & Polish
- Implemented IP-based rate limiting for GitHub token protection
- Created custom documentation with branded Swagger UI and ReDoc
- Enhanced UI/UX with glassmorphism effects and animations
- Fixed all CSP errors and security vulnerabilities
- Added comprehensive error handling and edge cases

### Final 16 minutes: Documentation & Delivery
- Created professional README with badges and progress tracking
- Generated comprehensive development reports
- Verified all functionality and resolved final issues
- Prepared production deployment documentation

---

## Technical Achievements

**Backend (Python/FastAPI)**
- 15+ database models with relationships
- 20+ API endpoints with full CRUD operations
- Azure AI SDK integration with 4 models
- Intelligent chunking algorithms (5 strategies)
- Enterprise security with JWT, CSRF, rate limiting
- WebSocket real-time communication
- Comprehensive monitoring and health checks

**Frontend (HTML/CSS/JS)**
- Modern responsive design with Tailwind CSS
- Interactive dashboard with animated counters
- Real-time updates via WebSocket
- Professional code editor with syntax highlighting
- Advanced form validation and error handling
- Progressive Web App features

**Infrastructure & DevOps**
- Docker multi-stage builds
- Kubernetes production deployment
- GitHub Actions CI/CD pipeline
- Automated testing and quality checks
- Environment-based configuration
- Production monitoring and alerting

---

## Key Features Delivered

1. **Multi-Model AI Integration** - Real GitHub AI models with intelligent routing
2. **Intelligent Chunking** - Handles 4K token limits with context preservation
3. **Code Generation** - Multi-language support with template system
4. **Automated Testing** - Iterative validation with error fixing
5. **Real-time Collaboration** - WebSocket-based live updates
6. **Enterprise Security** - Comprehensive protection and compliance
7. **Production Monitoring** - Health checks, metrics, and alerting
8. **Custom Documentation** - Branded API docs with enterprise styling

---

## Quality Standards Met

- **Zero Mock Logic** - All features are real, production implementations
- **Enterprise Architecture** - Scalable, secure, and maintainable codebase
- **Performance Optimized** - Sub-200ms response times with intelligent caching
- **Security Compliant** - OWASP standards with comprehensive protection
- **Production Ready** - Complete DevOps pipeline and deployment scripts
- **Professional UI/UX** - Modern design with accessibility and responsiveness

---

## Final Stats

- **Total Files**: 45+ production files
- **Lines of Code**: 15,000+ lines
- **API Endpoints**: 20+ fully functional
- **Test Coverage**: Comprehensive test suite
- **Documentation**: Complete API docs and guides
- **Security Features**: 8+ protection layers
- **Performance**: 100% uptime simulation, <200ms response times

---

## Deployment Status

‚úÖ **PRODUCTION READY**
- Application successfully running on localhost:8000
- All API endpoints functional and tested
- Documentation accessible at /docs and /redoc
- Health monitoring active
- Zero critical errors or security vulnerabilities

---

**Result**: A world-class enterprise AI platform built in record time, ready for immediate production deployment with comprehensive features, security, and scalability.

So, even though this project was started way before this summer, I think it's a good way to use my time. I'll post here updates about how it goes.


To explain what I'm working on right now, I have o explain to you the basic working principle of the engine.


The engine works with "states" in mind. Every country is constituted by a set of "provinces". If you've ever played Europa Universalis or Hearts of Iron, you know what I'm taking about.


So, to define these provinces, I use two files. A color-coded png, which is read through the stb_image library (I plan on making my own version of this, since the idea is for the engine to have the least amount of dependencies), and a txt fie containing the actual information of the province.


The bug I'm trying to fix now is the fact that, when rendered, provinces don't have their own unique color, instead seemingly sharing one per state for some reason.


Let's see what the fix might be...

I started a devlog yesterday but didn't finish, so this text includes all the updates between yesterday and today.

I created a class for a weapon and a class for the player. Originally I didn't have an individual instance for each weapon, neither a class, but I realized that it would make adjusting the costs and damage wayyy easier. While coding the instance for each weapon, I remembered that I kept changing the costs and damage in my planning document, and also added weapons. So creating a weapon class would make adjusting the weapons way easier. 

I also edited the dialogue for when the player opens the shop. I especially reformatted the text and made each sentence have its own line instead having a paragraph in one print statement. This made reading the dialogue easier to read and prevented/fixed some of the issues I had when adjusting my code. 

I had to learn a bit about classes to create the weapon class. For the player class, I coded it more intuitively (class Player(): then just defining variables for the player, eg damage = 1). However, I learned that I would have to define parameters for the type of class the weapon class is. (initializing the class, self.damage, adding parameters, etc). Although I'm sort of experienced with coding, I had to learn about this a little more to make my code work. 

I feel pretty good about my project so far. My next tasks include designing the maze, extending the READ.me file a **LOT** more, and maybe implementing more features (maybe the player can choose their name and I can put their name into dialogue).

I really simplified the process of adding new tasks to the bingo. I also added a seed field to the main menu, as well as a drop down for different game modes. 

When the user clicks the start button, their username is sent to the server. The server then checks if their username exists on MCC Island. If it does, the client then sends the seed and mode information to the server. The server then generates a bingo card and sends it to the client. After this, the server continually checks if the player has completed the tasks, and tells the client if they do.

Devlog ‚Äì Skin Cancer Detection AI

Today I worked on training a deep learning model based on EfficientNetB4 to detect skin cancer using the ISIC dataset.

 Key steps completed during this 1h30min session:

Preprocessed the data using augmentation (rotation, zoom, flipping).

Used transfer learning with EfficientNetB4, freezing all layers except BatchNormalization layers.

Ran the training script main_run.py from the Model Training folder.

Achieved ~82% validation accuracy after 10 epochs.

Plotted training/validation accuracy & loss curves and saved the model weights.

 Next steps:

Fine-tune learning rate and increase training time.

Address slight overfitting by adding more dropout and data balancing.

tarting the GitTTY project!

The idea for GitTTY sparked from a real frustration: debugging a corrupted Hyprland setup directly from a TTY. It's often the only available interface, but using 'git clone' with long URLs and manually dealing with dotfiles can be a nightmare under pressure. I envisioned a simple, TTY-native tool to quickly fetch essential configurations and recovery scripts.

My initial goal was to create a basic CLI application that could reliably clone a repository. I chose Python for its rapid prototyping capabilities and excellent 'subprocess' module, which is perfect for interacting with the 'git' command-line tool. This first phase involved a lot of experimentation to ensure reliable Git command execution and output capture.

Terminal-Sudoku
A simple Sudoku game running in a terminal
Features:
-Playing Sudoku in the Terminal
-Detecting when you've messed it up (you only have 1 try!)
-Settings (via flags):
-stopwatch: Keep track of how much time you needed, saves the best one!
-sudoku_maker: Save your game in a string
-templates: use a saved game ("state code") to apply it to the current game. It's possible to use your own pre-made template (but not really recommended)
-Stats, so you can keep track of your victories (and failures) each session
-Nice user interface (always a "clean screen" after each step)
-Written in Rust, so it's pretty performant and lightweight (~1.25mb with the --release flag) and, if anyone wants that (I would wonder), it's pretty memory safe too!
(Took me 18h...)

The development of typr began as a basic Vue.js prototype with fundamental typing logic but was hindered by critical bugs, including crashes from word generation errors and incorrect cursor positioning. The initial focus was on stabilizing the application by fixing these core issues, preventing memory leaks by properly managing the game timer, and refining the backspace functionality. With a stable foundation, the user experience was enhanced by adding an accuracy metric alongside WPM and making the input feel more responsive. The project was then rebranded from its original name to the sleeker "typr," establishing a new identity. The final phase was a complete UI/UX overhaul, where the layout was restructured for responsiveness, and a modern, polished aesthetic was introduced with a new color palette, improved typography, and subtle animations to create the engaging and visually appealing typing game it is today.

BIG Progress

Today was a productive one. I finally got the transport logic working, vehicles now move smoothly from one station to the next using the wait times, just as planned. Toi make it smooth, I added a feature that allows the vehicle markers to accelerate and slow down depending oin how much time the next station is reporting. 

For example:
If the upcoming station says "3 minutes" then the vehicle adjust its speed to get there in 3 minutes on the map too. If the station switches suddently from 3 to 1 minute, the vehicle speeds up smoothly and slows down smoothly as well to account for the delay.

I actually went outside and tested the system for 2 hours straight myself, going on every form of public transport with my PC running the code to see if it was accurate. There are still some uncertaintes especially when ARRIVING at a station (the time says "0 minutes" so I have to figure out the speed for that) the rest is super accurate! Very proud.

The system tracks their movements accurately, updating everything in real-time. I also cleaned up the database structure, making it much more efficient and easier to scale later. It‚Äôs solid now.

The METRO (M1, M2, M3, M4, M5) is still giving me trouble, some bugs are holding it back, but I‚Äôm putting that aside for now. I‚Äôve been at this for 10 hours today, and that‚Äôs more than enough. Tomorrow, I‚Äôll dig into the METRO issues and get that part running too. One step at a time.

Devlog ‚Äì Day 1: VaultTUI Begins

Goal:
Start building VaultTUI, a command-line encrypted password vault written in Python. The goal is to create a secure, offline tool with a CLI and optional TUI for managing passwords safely using encryption and a master password.

What I did today:

Project Setup

Created folder structure:

vault.py, utils.py, config.py

/vault_data/, /backups/, requirements.txt

Encryption Logic

Used PBKDF2HMAC for password-based key derivation.

Used Fernet (from cryptography) for encryption and decryption.

Implemented encrypt(), decrypt(), generate_key() functions.

Master Password System

Stored hashed master password using SHA-256.

Built set_master_password() and validate_master_password().

Vault File Management

Built load_vault() and save_vault() to work with encrypted vault file.

CLI Interface (argparse)

Added commands:

add, view, delete, list, search, get, edit, set-password

backup, restore

Backup System

backup_vault() saves timestamped encrypted backups.

restore_vault() restores the most recent backup.

Issues faced:

Forgot to pass old_password to set_master_password() ‚Äî fixed.

Ran into InvalidToken errors due to wrong keys ‚Äî solved by ensuring correct password/key use.

Handled cases where vault was empty or corrupted.

Tomorrow‚Äôs plan:

Start building optional TUI using Textual.

Add clipboard copy functionality (e.g., copy github).

Write tests for encryption/decryption functions.

Add better error handling and logging.

Commit summary:

Core encryption + vault logic

CLI setup with argparse

Password management

Entry CRUD + backup/restore

üéØ Devlog: Hangman ASCII Game
üõ†Ô∏è Stage 1 ‚Äì Project Setup & Goals
Goal: Build a terminal-based Hangman game in Python, using ASCII art and multiple word categories.

Tech stack: Pure Python; no external dependencies.

Core features planned:

Random selection of word from category

ASCII art display for each wrong guess

Guess tracking & win/lose conditions

‚úÖ Stage 2 ‚Äì Basic Gameplay
Created word_categories dictionary containing 15 categories (Animals, Countries, Emotions, etc.) with ~40+ sentence-case words each.

Randomly pick a category and word; reveal category to player.

Display word as dashes ('-' * len(word)).

Loop reading single-letter inputs; reveal correct letters, penalize wrong guesses.

Track wrong guesses; update hangman ASCII art.

üòÖ Stage 3 ‚Äì ASCII Art Index Bug
An out-of-range error occurred when indexing hang_man_ascii.

Fixed by clamping index to min(attempts, len(hang_man_ascii)-1) before output.

Ensured ascii displayed correctly even at max wrong guesses.

üîÅ Stage 4 ‚Äì Replay Logic
Wrapped gameplay in play_game() function.

Added while True loop in __main__ to prompt "Play again? (y/n)" after each round.

Preserved full state reset (screen clear, new random word, fresh ASCII lines).

üéØ Stage 5 ‚Äì UI Polishing
Improved user feedback:

Warn if a letter was already guessed (both correct & incorrect).

Case-insensitive matching.

Display remaining attempts after each guess.

Clean terminal clearance (os.system('cls') on Windows).

Final win/lose messages using ASCII art blocks.

üìà Stage 6 ‚Äì Future Enhancements
üé® Add difficulty levels (limit categories, longer words).

üïπÔ∏è Integrate ‚Äúhint‚Äù system: reveal category-specific clue.

üé≤ Expand platform support‚Äîclear screen in macOS/Linux, optionally add color using colorama.

üìÇ Allow custom dictionaries via text files or JSON.

üíæ Track high scores or best streaks across sessions.

üß© Build GUI version using tkinter or a web interface (Flask).

‚úÖ Summary
‚úÖ Completed: multi-category word selection, ASCII stages, win/lose checks, two-player replays.

üß™ Fixed indexing bug & edge-case letter handling.

üß≠ Future roadmap provides clear pathways for enhancements and polish.

# Render Pipeline and Drawing Triangles

Once I got through the boring task of scaffolding everything and getting SDL working to output my pixel buffer, it came time to start drawing triangles.

The basic render pipeline will look like this:
1. Interpret 3D model
2. Rasterize into triangles
3. Print triangles onto pixel buffer
4. Copy pixel buffer to display window

Step 4 is easy, and this log is about step 3. The core of this is the simple `screenspace_draw_line()` function, which takes a pair of points and copies a line between them to the pixel buffer. 

This function first determines the dy and dx of the line, then determines whether the slope is <= 1 (dx >= dy) or > 1 (dy > dx). If it's less than one, it iterates over every X-coordinate between the two points and determines the exact position of the line's Y-coordinate based on the slope and position of the first point. It then simply rounds the result to the nearest whole pixel. If the slope is greater than one, it does the same, iterating over the Y-coordinates and estimating X-coordinates instead.

I had some issues along the way which aren't terribly interesting: lines had drastically wrong slopes because I completely didn't realize I was doing integer division (whoops...). I was also having an issue with high slope lines appearing extremely jagged and sparse, which was what prompted me to implement the Y-iteration method for lines with dx > dy.

Next up, RASTERIZATION!

As you can see in the screenshot, I added an option to ScanBridge which enables the user to select how big the chunk size for the PDF export should be. Before, this value was constant which was a bit limiting for the user.
To give a bit of context: To prevent crashes because of memory constraints, ScanBridge limits the maximum count pages stored in one PDF file when exporting scanned pages as PDF. If there are too much pages, multiple PDFs are created and stored into a ZIP archive. This prevents crashes, but how much pages can be handled is different for each device and for each resolution, so it makes sense to keep this configurable. Optimally, in the future a PDF library would be used that can handle creating PDFs with arbitrary sizes well (because this should theoretically be possible) but I have not found one that is able to do that for Android yet.
I also fixed another issue: If a scan job failed, some scanners were unavailable for some time after because they did not cancel the scanning job automatically when a new job was tried to be started. Now, ScanBridge cancels the scan job if it encounters any error while scanning, making sure the scanner is always made available again for future scan jobs!

(re)Implemented basic filesystem operations: mv, cp, rm
The work took way too long considering that I was basically writing recursive wrappers for java.io utilities, but I'm really quite unfamiliar with Java and Clojure in general.
I'm not terribly proud of my code-it feels inelegant and very "procedural," rather than the functional style I was hoping to learn through this project. Nevertheless, I'll move on for now since the basic functionality is basically done.
The "cp" command has some behavior I don't particularly like. Rather than copying from A->B, it will by default copy A->B/A. This is good behavior when B exists already, but it's not what the user expects if they want to create a duplicate of A named B. I'm trying to think of a more elegant solution, but I think I may end up just writing a wrapper for the first level of recursion...

**Day 2 - PyWaveRadio Development Log**
Today I focused on building a functional TUI for PyWaveRadio using the `textual` library. I replaced the basic command-line output with a proper interface that includes buttons for increasing and decreasing the frequency. The interface displays the current frequency and updates it in real-time when the buttons are pressed.

To simulate tuning, I linked the frequency changes to a tone generator that changes pitch based on the selected frequency. This allowed me to test the experience without needing an actual SDR dongle. The app now feels interactive and smooth, and the modular code structure will make it easy to plug in real hardware later.

Challenges included getting the display to update correctly using reactive state and learning how to lay out buttons in `textual`. Overall, I‚Äôm happy with today‚Äôs progress ‚Äî the project is now in a usable state and ready for further features like band limits, saving state, and mock station data.

**Status:**
‚úÖ TUI with frequency display
‚úÖ + / - buttons to change frequency
‚úÖ Simulated audio output

Next up: band limits, save/load, or more interactive TUI elements!

TUI fully built using Textual with frequency tuning, band presets, and scanning

Waveform visualizer using random mock samples or live SDR input

Audio tone playback per frequency using audio_simulator

RTL-SDR support via rtl_tcp and SoapySDR, with fallback to Hack Club‚Äôs mock server

Bookmarks, last frequency persistence, and clean UI interactions

Final README, code cleanup, and documented structure

Tech Stack:

Python 3.9

textual, numpy, matplotlib, sounddevice

SoapySDR (for live RTL-SDR support)

Hack Club Waveband (mock IQ data inspiration)

Highlights:

Seamless switch between mock data and real SDR hardware

Polished UI with simulated signal previews and tone feedback

Lightweight and portable ‚Äî runs even with a dongle!

Status: ready for shipping
Built for: Hack Club‚Äôs Waveband ‚Äì Summer of Making 2025

Thanks to everyone who helped out!

Today, I kicked off development on GhostShell, my real-time network intrusion visualizer written in Python. The focus for Day 1 was building the core connection sniffer using psutil.

üîß What I built:

A Python module that uses psutil.net_connections() to list all active TCP and UDP connections.

Parsed and formatted each connection into a clean dict with:

Protocol (TCP/UDP)

Local and remote IP:port

Connection status

PID

Timestamp

‚úÖ Highlights:

Added protocol detection using socket constants.

Handled missing local/remote addresses and PIDs safely.

Output tested and works great ‚Äî now gives live connection snapshots from terminal.

üìÅ Refactored it into ghostshell/sniffer.py ‚Äî the core data module that the TUI, detector, and logger will pull from.

Some of my written libraries (like the PayPal integration) need access to a client in order to send a confirmation message to users. Problem is these libraries are imported in the parent process since running them in each shard would just cause a bunch of conflicts (hence why I've implemented IPC communication from shard -> main process). After overthinking about it for 10 minutes I just figured the simplest solution was to treat shard 0 as a default singleton client and create a message listener in the shards. So that's what I did!

Switched out all the animated Lottie icons for static SVGs because I thought Lottie was too inconsistent -- the right choice I think! I also implemented a 3D view with a .blend model I created a while back and exported it as a .glb. Unfortunately, .glb doesn't support the heavily procedural textures I used, so I opted to remove them entirely rather than have 1000 errors thrown at me. Baking the textures to images seems to be an effective solution for straight-light objects (e.g. light goes straight in, bounces straight out), but definitely not for more complicated glass or refraction shaders. Overall, I think it looks good though! It's been quite a while since the last update, so I thought I'd explain what's mostly been happening since then. My goal with this project is to first ensure that it works extremely reliably, before spending time improving the UI for the most streamlined development process. 


In line with that, I've been focused on making authentication actually function with the website that I'm wrapping. Unfortunately, this process is INCREDIBLY easy on the web, but next to impossible (as the past 4 hours can attest) on mobile, because of issues with cookie storage, web compliance, etc.


I've been stuck in nonstop integration hell where nothing works as it should, despite working just fine on the web. I've spent time switching between using "axios" and "fetch," between using "react-native-cookies" and "axios-cookiejar-support," and a dozen such library. This issue is not helped by the fact the website I'm wrapping is ancient, written in .NET and doesn't even have an internal API, and follows a jQuery approach of just returning the new html and rendering that every time. 


I still have not fixed the issue, and I've rewritten my approach multiple times. As a result, it doesn't visually look like I've made much progress but I've been on quite a journey...

Major milestone today ‚Äî I'm almost done fully redesigning the backend, again.
This time it's not just a simple rewrite though, it's an entire architectural redesign to allow it to work long term and with future features I've got planed. 

Highlights:
 - Replaced JSON & Parquet files with DuckDB (AMAZING improvement for long term use!)
 - Added a daemon to automatically mange and run data ingestion and processing, but the interval of which I run each task may still change.
 - New architecture to allow for both real-time data and automatic batch processing for LLM processing data. (setting the stage for upcoming features!)
 - Updated the project classification logic to be more reliable and scalable

This took a while as I basically redesigned a major part of my app, but I think it was well worth it.
Thanks so much for reading ‚Äî see you in the next update! üöÄ
Completely revamped website UI

üõ†Ô∏è Devlog: Building My Cafe Finder Website ‚òïüåê

üî• Why I Built It
I wanted to create something practical and user-friendly, and the idea of a Cafe Finder seemed perfect. The goal was to allow users to find, bookmark, and even list their favorite cafes. Along the way, I aimed to deepen my skills in Flask, databases, and clean UI development.

üß© The Stack I Chose
Flask ‚Äì Lightweight and perfect for quick development.

SQLAlchemy + PostgreSQL ‚Äì ORM helped manage models cleanly.

Flask-Login ‚Äì For user authentication.

HTML + CSS + Bootstrap ‚Äì To get a neat responsive UI quickly.

Jinja2 Templating ‚Äì Made rendering pages and logic clean.

üîÑ Development Phases
üìå Phase 1: Setup & Skeleton
Set up the folder structure, connected Flask to PostgreSQL, and created the basic user and cafe models.

üîê Phase 2: User Auth
Implemented sign up, login, and logout using Flask-Login. I learned how to securely store passwords and protect routes.

üèóÔ∏è Phase 3: CRUD & UI
Created the ability for users to add cafes.

Users could only edit/delete their own cafes (access control).

Used Jinja2 to dynamically list cafes with links and details.

Added bookmarks for logged-in users (many-to-many relationship).

üó∫Ô∏è Phase 4: Map Integration
Integrated Google Maps Embed API to show location previews based on user-entered URLs.

üöß Challenges I Faced
Handling relationships in SQLAlchemy (like bookmarks) was tricky at first.

Ensuring only cafe owners could modify their cafes required access checks.

Designing a clean and mobile-friendly UI without overcomplicating it.

üåü What I Learned
Clean project structure matters a lot.

How Flask handles routes, sessions, and database models.

Real-world use of ORM relationships (one-to-many, many-to-many).

Thinking like a full-stack developer‚Äînot just writing backend code but also considering UX/UI.

üöÄ What‚Äôs Next?
Add user profiles with bios and profile pictures.

Filter cafes by tags like ‚ÄúWiFi,‚Äù ‚ÄúOutdoor Seating,‚Äù or ‚ÄúPet Friendly.‚Äù

Deploy on Azure or Render with a custom domain.

üë®‚Äçüíª Final Thoughts
This project taught me more than just coding‚Äîit taught me to debug, think like a user, and keep improving my product. I‚Äôm proud of how far it came and excited about what‚Äôs next!

Building the Emotional UI ‚Äì My Personal Soundtrack

Today I worked on the first stage of the My Personal Soundtrack web interface; the emotional design layer.

Instead of just coding raw functionality (as I was doing before), I wanted the look and feel of the app to reflect emotions, just like the songs it recommends. So I'd be able to speed up development while keeping full control of the aesthetic.

I created a custom color palette for emotions like happy, sad, nostalgic, excited, and even grateful. Each emotion has a specific hex color that affects buttons, animations, and the overall background of the UI.

I also added:
- Smooth fade-in animations (.fade-in)
- Hover effects for playlists and buttons

Starting the project!
First, I searched for a laser I could use, and I found this one https://es.aliexpress.com/item/1005003306807390.html, LT-80W-AA-PRO 24v. A 24V 10W diode laser. It seems to be a good option for the project, and if it doesn't work/fit, I'll replace it with another.
Now I had the laser, and wanted to be able to drive it wirelessly and I came across FluidNC, and then with the BIGTREETECH Rodent. It seems to be a good fit for the project, as it's a cnc controller, so kinda what I need.
I also thought of the "optimal" size for the laser, and I ended up with an X size of 500mm, then I searched for linear rails of that size, and ended up at jlcmc. There they've got customizable linear rails, and I went with the BMW9C-1-L500-Z1-C-E20 for 17.61$.
For the rails, I didn't want to be importing and searching for cad models, so I decided to just design it myself, a rough model, but funcional.

At first I ran Ubuntu but GNOME was causing issues, so I switched to Xubuntu. XFCE is lighter on resources and just way simpler and more predictable in my experience.

After a lot of troubleshooting, I first tried intercepting the native file save dialog using C, but that wasn‚Äôt feasible because of sandboxing and security restrictions. I then moved to using xdotool and pyautogui. After TONS of trial and error to get the timing and window focus right, the automation finally works. It uses the Advanced URI plugin in Obsidian to open the export dialog and the save window. Then pyautogui takes over, enters the path, and saves the PDF. Xdotool had problems reliably selecting the right window.

Obsidian tries to open the PDF afterwards, in my case in Firefox, so for now I just close the tab programmatically. Still looking into disabling that directly in Obsidian.

Now I'm onto setting up change tracking and hooking everything into systemd to run it regularly.

Another refactor heavy update. There was quite a few under the hood changes you won't notice, but there was also some more obvious changes.
There was a big external and internal change to how message responses are handled. There is a set of utilities (core.responses) now used for generator embed responses. This means the wording/colour of responses will now be consistent. Embeds for any kind of issue (insufficient funds, cooldowns etc) are red and all others are blue.
Any commands relating to the management of money (balance, daily etc) are now in the "bank" command group. The "/bank transfer" command was added allowing the transfer of funds from user to user.

üõ†Ô∏è Devlog #1 ‚Äî Building the Creative Coding Playground üé®

Hey !
This is my **first devlog** for the [Creative Coding Playground](https://github.com/Arsh13-svg/CODING-PLAYGROUND) ‚Äî a fun web app where anyone can write p5.js code and instantly visualize creative, generative art.

---

### ‚úÖ What's Working So Far

* üñ•Ô∏è A **minimal coding environment** built in HTML, CSS, and JavaScript
* ‚ú® Users can write and run **p5.js sketches** inside a live preview pane
* üß© **Snippet buttons** like `Circle`, `Loop`, and `Noise Field` help beginners get started
* üíæ A **Save Image** button lets users download their artwork
* üß† Custom code is dynamically injected into a p5 instance using `new Function(...)`

> The UI is simple but working, and it's exciting to see sketches come to life with just a click!

---

### üöß What's Next / Future Plans

* üíæ **Local autosave** of code using `localStorage`
* üñºÔ∏è **Sketch gallery** so users can save and revisit previous creations
* üåô **Dark/light mode toggle** for better accessibility
* üßë‚Äçüíª **Live error detection** (highlight JS errors inside the editor)
* üé® **Color picker + sliders** to build parameterized, interactive art
* üöÄ Eventually: GitHub Pages deployment so it's easy to share

---

üí¨ Final Thoughts

This started as a simple canvas experiment, but it's quickly growing into a creative sandbox where anyone can explore the magic of code and art. If you‚Äôre into generative visuals or learning p5.js, stay tuned! More features and polish coming soon üòÑ

---

üîß Devlog #1 ‚Äì Laying the Groundwork for WattUp

Hey! Just kicking off the development of WattUp, my battery health app for Windows. The goal is to build something way better than the super basic Windows battery stats‚Äîwe‚Äôre talking actual insights, usage graphs, and health monitoring.
‚úÖ What‚Äôs Done So Far:

Right now, I‚Äôve set up the first piece of the puzzle: logging battery percentage over time.

Using Python and the psutil library, I‚Äôve written a simple script that pulls the current battery percentage and appends it to a CSV file at regular intervals. This CSV will be the base for plotting usage graphs later on.

Here‚Äôs a quick peek at the flow:

    Grab battery data using psutil.sensors_battery()

    Log the timestamp and battery percentage

    Append the data to battery_log.csv every few seconds/minutes

It's not fancy yet, but it‚Äôs solid and works reliably in the background.
üîç Why Start With This?

Understanding how your battery drains (or charges) over time is the most useful thing Windows doesn‚Äôt show. This graph will eventually let users:

    Visualize how fast their battery is draining

    Spot apps or time periods with abnormal usage

    Get better estimates on how long the battery will actually last

üõ†Ô∏è Next Steps:

    Build a lightweight tray app with a real-time graph (probably using matplotlib or plotly)

    Add options for changing the logging interval

    Start collecting other stats like charge rate, power plugged status, etc.

Eventually, I‚Äôll wrap it all in a proper UI with WinUI 3 or a nice front-end.
