I transitioned the scoring system to Net Words Per Minute (Net WPM) to provide a more accurate and fair assessment of typing skill by factoring in errors. Alongside this, the post-race screen now clearly displays Net WPM and total errors, it gave it a complete overhaul. The old summary screen has been replaced with a much cleaner leaderboard that ranks players by performance. I also improved the personal performance chart. The hardest task I tackled was fixing a desynchronization bug that occurred when toggling the "Scrolling View" mid-race. My previous implementation would destroy and recreate the UI, causing the user's typed text to be lost visually and marking all subsequent characters as incorrect. To fix this, I refactored the logic to use a single, persistent text input that simply moves between two views. Now, instead of recreating everything, I just toggle the visibility of the views, which preserves the race state perfectly and makes the feature seamless and stable. Finally, I fixed a visual bug causing player cards to misalign. The issue stemmed from a conflict between grid styles in the static HTML and the dynamic JavaScript. I resolved it by removing the layout classes from the HTML, giving the JavaScript full control over the grid, which now aligns the cards correctly.

üß† The Idea
We live in a world full of noise ‚Äî social media, judgment, pressure to perform, and the constant feeling of being watched or compared.
What if there was a space where none of that existed?

Anon Board is a personal side project designed to be just that:

A quiet, anonymous place where people can drop their thoughts, emotions, or small confessions ‚Äî and realize they‚Äôre not alone.

No accounts.
No names.
No likes.
Just feelings, visualized as colors and words.

üéØ The Goal
Let people share how they feel without fear

Show others that someone, somewhere, feels the same

Create a minimal, safe emotional space on the internet

üß© The Concept
Every post is a short sentence (e.g. ‚ÄúI feel lost‚Äù), submitted anonymously.
Each message is assigned a color that represents an emotion:
üîµ blue = sadness
üî¥ red = anger
üü¢ green = hope
‚ö™ white = emptiness
üü° yellow = joy
üü£ purple = anxiety/fear

All posts appear as colored dots on a dark emotional map.
Hovering or tapping a dot reveals the short message.
That‚Äôs it. No pressure. No identity.

üñåÔ∏è Inspirations
Mental health journaling apps

Public confession walls

Color-based therapy models

The human need to be heard (even silently)

üõë Bluetooth Connectivity ‚Äî A Hard Lesson Learned

I spent the weekend trying to add Bluetooth access to NetTool, aiming to let users connect directly to the dashboard via Bluetooth PAN or RFCOMM. Unfortunately‚Ä¶ no dice.

Bluetooth tethering on Linux (especially Raspberry Pi) is messy pand is deprecated, and setting up a Bluetooth PAN or serial console requires complex service configs. I tried multiple tutorials, daemon setups, and service files‚Äîbut couldn‚Äôt get it reliable or stable.

Bottom line: Bluetooth support in this release is a dead end. I‚Äôll shelve it for now and focus back on Wi‚ÄëFi and Ethernet platforms that actually work.

More detailed image assets with higher resolution will definitely improve this sense of space, but that won't come until the later stages of the project. I'll keep using these temporary assets just to make sure the code works first.
Basic idea of how it works:
when you move the mouse in a direction, the program tracks that and moves the background in the opposite direction, making it appear as if your character looked over there. However it puts in the limitation that your character is glued to the ground and cannot move like a real 3D game.

Got WASM to work, and I can now order (groups of) templates depending on their "score" so that identities come before other templates 100% of the time (as seen on the image, the general identity comes before the one used in number division). Also drafted up an algorithm that handles the integer part in division that is similar to how us, humans do it (approximation: measure the magnitude and gradually set the thousands, hundreds, tens, etc. digits). This allows me to have the engine actually explain how to do division (without simply stating that the integer part of "10 / 4" is 2), and teaches the user the "skill" more experienced people have.

well... its been almost five hours of coding for what i knew would take forever.. and im nowhere near done with today's task.

what i got done:
* fixed a couple bugs in my code that reads data from PlayStation SFO files that returned incorrect data (returning 32-bit integers for 16-bit integers, accidentally decoded as ASCII instead of UTF-8, that sort of thing)
* instead of pretending every value is encoded as UTF-8, my SFO parser now respects the data type the SFO file has. turns out they weren't very inventive, because the only options are UTF-8 strings or unsigned 32-bit integers :D
* made the code that reads null-terminated strings from SFO files hopefully faster, by reading 64-byte chunks and checking it for NUL bytes instead of reading one byte at a time. i dont think it made any effect on execution time.

and then the really big, time consuming thing. i went through the PS3 Dev Wiki looking for important-looking values, with the goal of representing a PS3 PARAM.SFO (main metadata file on PS3) file as a C# class. Going through the *very long* list of properties these files *might* have (none of them are required i dont think), i picked out the ones that would be more impressive first (title, category, supported resolutions, that sort of thing) and brought them out of the directory i shoved them into yesterday. i've even added some support for changing the data in these files, and tomorrow I think i'll work on serializing the class back into an SFO file. I'm happy with my progress so far, and i know a lot more about C# enums than i thought i'd ever need lol

Anyway, I've attached a little demo of what I'm able to get out of these files alone. There's still a lot of bugs I need to fix but it mostly works!!

I've fully switched to using program-counter for fetching and executing instructions.

I've started implementing hardware part of the 6502 as well. I've created a pins struct that determines each pin's state (high or low). 

One of the differences from the real chip is that we don't check for high -> low, we keep the pin values as booleans (high as true, low as false) and just set handled pins to high. I am not sure if this is the best way to do it, it could get pretty complicated if you wanted to replicate the chip's behaviour while using this module.

Now, for the pins to work, we need a notion of 'cycles' in our emulator. We have been just implementing and executing instructions directly, but in 6502 each instruction has a specified amount of cycles and clock pins signal a cycle. This is also needed for writing to/reading from address and data bus.

So how to do it then? There are a few ways but before that, I think it would be better if we switched to using x86 assembly instead of coding this by hand, which can get pretty complicated pretty quickly. This would also make our emulator a kind of 'JIT' compiler :) 

So the next step would be starting on that, and it can make the code faster too I think.

18/06/2025: Fixed detection area issue
My goal was to make the detection area of the toolbar sense when the mouse entered it, whether it was dragging a gate or not. The issue was that the detection area could not properly detect our mouse when it was dragging a gate. To solve it, I made my gate script emit a signal when a gate is being dragged and when it stops being dragged. I then connected those signals to functions in my base_level class to change the signals that the detection area would be checking for (either area_entered or mouse_entered)

# Devlog: June 22, 2025

**Refactoring for Scalability, Configurability, and New Features**

Today's updates focus on making the transcoder more robust, configurable, and feature-rich. I've refactored key parts of the application to improve performance and maintainability, and I've added several new API endpoints to enhance its capabilities.

**Here‚Äôs a summary of the key changes:**

* **Configuration via Environment Variables:**
  I've externalized several settings into environment variables (`GENERATE_DASH`, `GENERATE_SUBTITLES`, `THUMBNAIL_WIDTH`, `LAMBDA_FUNCTION_URL`). This allows for greater flexibility in deploying and managing the application without requiring code changes.

* **Efficient Streaming with S3 Pre-signed URLs:**
  The `/stream/` endpoint has been completely overhauled. Instead of proxying video data through the Lambda function, it now generates and redirects to a secure, time-limited S3 pre-signed URL. This offloads the bandwidth-intensive work to S3, resulting in a significant performance boost and cost savings.

* **Enhanced API and Asset Management:**

  * **Decoupled IDs:** The application now uses a redirect system to map the original video filename to a unique, content-based processing ID (its MD5 hash). This makes the API more stable and decouples it from the original filename.
  * **DELETE Endpoint:** A new `DELETE /api/video/<video_id>` endpoint has been added, allowing for the complete removal of a video and all its associated processed files.
  * **In-Progress Status:** A new `/api/transcoding_status` endpoint provides a way to monitor jobs that are currently being processed.
  * **Automated Cleanup:** The application now automatically deletes temporary audio files from S3 after transcription is complete, helping to keep storage costs down.

* **Improved Thumbnails:**
  In addition to the VTT sprites for timeline previews, the application now generates a high-quality primary thumbnail from the middle of the video, providing a better visual representation in the video gallery.

# üöÄ Dev Log: Stichtted v3.0 Released

**Date:** June 23, 2025  
**By:** [S4k3t](https://github.com/Saketkesar)  
**Live Demo:** [üåê saketkesar.github.io/Stichtted](https://saketkesar.github.io/Stichtted/)

---

## ‚ú® What‚Äôs New in v3.0

- üåå **Web3-themed Documentation Site**  
  ‚Üí Now live with a galaxy background and hacker aesthetics.  
  ‚Üí Includes full command usage, features, and sample outputs.  
  ‚Üí Visit: [saketkesar.github.io/Stichtted](https://saketkesar.github.io/Stichtted/)

- üìÅ **Support for .pcap and .pcapng**  
  ‚Üí Analyze both legacy and modern packet capture formats.

- üîç **Enhanced Detection Engine**  
  ‚Üí Added **PyShark** integration for deep inspection.  
  ‚Üí Extracts from:
    - HTTP headers & bodies  
    - DNS queries & tunneling detection  
    - FTP/SMTP payloads  
    - TCP stream reassembly  

- ‚úÖ **Total Hits + Match Locations**  
  ‚Üí Displays all occurrences with exact packet index, context, and stream summary.

- üé® **New Terminal Banner**  
  ‚Üí Includes GitHub star link, aesthetic icons, and animated-style text output.

---

## üõ† Behind the Scenes

> This release took a big leap from just regex scanning to full protocol-aware deep packet inspection. The new architecture uses both **Scapy** and **PyShark** together for layered extraction. Inspired by real CTF challenges and forensic dumps.

---

## üß™ Next Goals

- ‚úèÔ∏è Add clipboard copy buttons to the docs site  
- üì¶ Ship a PyPI CLI version (`pip install stichtted`)  
- üîê TLS decryption support (if certs provided)  
- üåà Optional anime-style splash screen üß™  

---

Thanks to everyone who's supported this tool from v1.0.

üõ∞Ô∏è Built with caffeine, Scapy, and packet chaos.  
‚Äî `S4k3t`

Devlog Entry #5 ‚Äî Authentication Fully Integrated!
Date: June 18, 2025
Milestone: Login + Registration system complete

Today was all about building secure access into Zynk. Here's what got done:

‚úÖ What‚Äôs Working:
User Registration: New users can register with a username, email, and password.
Login System: Registered users can now log in with their email and password.
Password Security: Passwords are hashed using bcrypt before being stored in the database.
Session Management: Once logged in, users stay logged in using express-session.
Access Control: Protected routes (like /dashboard and /) now redirect unauthenticated users to /login.

Logout: Users can securely log out, clearing their session.

Challenges Faced:
Got a TypeError from misusing middleware ‚Äî solved by moving isAuthenticated into a proper middleware file instead of importing it directly from routes.
Initially couldn‚Äôt test login since no users existed. Fixed this by registering a test account manually via the form.

Next Steps:
Add flash messages for login errors (like "Invalid credentials").
Improve UI feedback in login/register pages.
Start building the actual Dashboard page content.

Zynk now has a locked door‚Äîand only the right key can open it üîê

Devlog #3 ‚Äî User model & Authentication System
Date: June 18, 2025

Progress:
I successfully connected my Node.js backend to MongoDB using Mongoose. Previously, my app didn‚Äôt specify the database name in the connection string, so I updated it to target my specific database, zynk, in my MongoDB Atlas cluster.

What I did:
Used the official MongoDB connection string format for a cloud-hosted database.

Added the database name zynk to the connection URI, so Mongoose knows which database to use.

Handled connection success and error messages to confirm connection status in the console.

This connection setup enables storing user data securely for my authentication system.

I even fixed many errors that did not make the code work and installed many packages to fix those errors.

I even updated some files like the registry.html, login.html etc to make the user model and authentication system work smoothly! :)

Devlog #2 ‚Äî Database Setup & Connection
Date: June 18, 2025
Progress:

Today, I connected my backend to MongoDB Atlas! After creating my free cluster, I set up a secure database user and used the connection string to link MongoDB to my app using Mongoose.

I also created a new file, db.js, and placed it inside the routes folder (though I may reorganize this later). With just a few lines of code, the app can now reliably connect to MongoDB. Super exciting seeing that üü¢ "Connected to MongoDB" message in my terminal!

Next Step:
I'll start creating a user model and API routes for registration and login. It's starting to feel real!

decided not to split the plate because splitting it would make it pretty difficult to print secure during shipping, so i'll probably use JLC3DP for this one part
discovered that JLC3DP PLA print has to have a minimum of 1cm height and their capabilities don't support 1.5mm height, but after some research I discovered that many people use FR4 as material for their plates, so I did a big brain move and exported the plate sketch as a DXF and imported it into kicad and just exported as gerber!
image

turns out that JLCPCB is pretty expensive for getting plates, so instead I decided to just get it via a resin print, which can support 1.5mm thick prints
replacing 1k ohm with C11702, since it's a basic part

Got some updates

TL;DR: Made some aesthetic changes + optimizations (didn't update about them so üòÖ)

Profile Page Animation Optimization (src/pages/[username]/index.js)
* Lazy-loaded animations: Only load GSAP animations when user has a link to animate
* Conditional loading: Skip animation setup entirely if no link exists
* Reduced SVG variants: Decreased from 6 to 3 animation variants
* Timeout delay: Added 100ms delay to prevent blocking initial render
* Cleanup on unmount: Proper cleanup to prevent memory leaks

Static Generation Improvements (src/pages/[username]/index.js)
* Post filtering: Filter published posts before processing to reduce work
* Post limiting: Limited to 20 most recent posts for faster loading
* Increased revalidation: Changed from 60s to 300s (5 minutes) for better caching
* Robust timestamp handling: Better handling of Firestore timestamp conversion

Explore Page Performance (src/pages/explore/index.js)
* Batch author fetching: Replaced individual author queries with single batch request
* Efficient author mapping: Created author lookup map for O(1) access
* Optimized database queries: Uses compound query with fallback for better performance
* Reduced redundant API calls: Prevents multiple simultaneous loading calls

Alright, devlog time again! So, here‚Äôs the tea: I totally got distracted by all the shiny-new-thing hype and dove head-first into DuckDB without actually checking if it was the right fit. I spent basically the entire last week wiring up my whole LifeLog backend to use DuckDB‚Äîfelt super productive‚Ä¶ until reality slapped me.

Turns out DuckDB only lets one reader or writer touch the file at a time. Guess what happens when the enrichment pipeline and the API both want in at once? Yeah‚Äîüí• race-condition city. How did I not see that coming?

Cue the record scratch: ‚ÄúWait, why am I fighting the database instead of actually continuing to work on the project?‚Äù
So today I went full tunnel-vision mode, spun up a local Postgres instance, and started porting everything over. I‚Äôm talking schema tweaks, ORM shenanigans, fresh config files‚Äîthe works. I basically lived in VS Code for, like, eight hours straight, but the crazy part is‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs almost done already. Since I‚Äôm still in version-zero territory, there were no migration scripts to worry about‚Äîjust rip-and-replace, run the tests, and boom: the app boots without screaming at me. üéâ
    
Moral of the story: research first, chase hype later. Anyway, that‚Äôs where LifeLog‚Äôs at right now. Next devlog will probably be about ironing out the last Postgres edge-cases.

Stay tuned!

# Devlog: June 23, 2025
Comprehensive Documentation and Architectural Refinements
Today's focus has been on a complete overhaul of the project's documentation and a formalization of its architecture. The goal was to create a comprehensive guide that not only explains how to deploy the application but also details its internal workings, configuration, and API.

Key updates include:

- **Detailed "How It Works" Section:** I've added a new section to the `README.md` that provides a step-by-step walkthrough of the entire video processing pipeline‚Äîfrom the initial browser upload to the final, streamable asset. This clarifies the role of each component, including the dual S3 triggers and the content-addressable storage strategy.

- ****Configuration and API Documentation:****

    - **Configuration Table:** All environment variables are now documented in a clear table, explaining their purpose and default values.
    - **API Endpoints Table:** The REST API is now fully documented, with a table listing all endpoints, their HTTP methods, and descriptions.

- **Granular Deployment Guide:** The deployment instructions have been significantly expanded and refined:

    - **IAM & CORS:** Added explicit JSON examples for the required IAM policies and S3 CORS configuration.
    - **Lambda Function URL:** The guide now centers on using a Lambda Function URL for direct access, which simplifies the architecture by removing the need for API Gateway.
    - **Dual S3 Triggers:** The instructions now detail the setup for two separate S3 triggers‚Äîone for new uploads and another to handle asynchronous results from services like Amazon Transcribe, preventing processing loops.

- **Enhanced Testing Information:** The testing section has been updated to clarify the use of moto for mocking AWS services, making it easier for others to run the unit tests locally.

This comprehensive documentation effort makes the project significantly more accessible, maintainable, and easier for others to understand, use, and contribute to.

So now I'm adding custom classes so that you can style the markdown-it image without making some global styles. Well, I'm a liar, I already added that. To do that, we simply take in more arguments in the exported function from the package, and then I had to figure out the logic to make it conditionally add the class with some ternary operators. Getting it right was actually funnily the hardest part but I did it anyway. A nifty command that exists is npm link (i use pnpm though), it allows you to access your package without publishing it by making a symlink (like the ones on your desktop) in the global folder for node modules. It updates every time you do pnpm build. Nifty as hell! Another important thing it to not forget to document changes like these, or else no one is going to find out unless their IDE suggests it to them because of typescript.

Did a bit more research on the 6502 to learn about how it works and whatnot. It's actually a really fascinating processor with some very interesting tradeoffs that paid off well for the time period and made it as interesting as it is today. The stack is actually only 256 bytes which meant it can't be used as it is today. There is also a really cool indexing system which can allow for really easy array operations and is honestly genius for the time period.

Adds file-based logging with timestamped entries

Introduces a `log_output` function to write log messages to timestamped daily files, ensuring thread-safe storage in a `.log` directory. Enhances logging by appending formatted output to both console and file, improving traceability and debugging.

I'm posting this short log in regards of my change to the project settings on summer of making. I checked the AI box, I was unsure if I really should. Anything after I added this here is almost never AI, and AI has never been able to do any of the actual code for me. However, it writes docs/readmes pretty well, and that's it. For anyone wondering if I "vibe coded" this project, absolutely not. Try it yourself, it can't comprehend nightly rust and alpha libraries like uefi. The libs change so often AI's data is always outdated, and it makes mistakes all over the place when you try to do things with raw pointers, memory addresses, and binary/bytes. The most AI code usage I'll do is "Copilot organize this file" and have it move functions around or cleanup imports.

Playing around with some of the EPA constants. Here's an updated analysis for Washington (turns out the last implementation had a few bugs). We can see that I Forgot's EPA is a more deflated version of their OPR (counting playoffs certainly helps here) and High Definition and Adna drop significantly in the rankings due to bad performances at-event. Actually, this isn't quite fair to OPR as I'm using Adna's overall best OPR whereas their event OPR was 115, a much more realistic estimate given their broken (and very penalty-prone) 7 samp. QC's EPA also drops in comparison to their OPR, since they broke for the end of quals. Overall quite happy with results so far, as it seems EPA adapts much more rapidly to latest performance, which is a crucial factor for scouting. Also, I excluded WCI this time so EV looks good :) 2nd best team in Washington btw #evdeserved1stpick

# üß™ STICHTTED v2.0 ‚Äì Dev Log

**Release Date:** 23 June 2025  
**Author:** S4k3t

---

## üöÄ What's New

### ‚úÖ TCP Stream Reassembly
- Reconstructs full TCP conversations
- Detects flags split across multiple packets

### ‚úÖ Recursive Encoding Detection
- Automatically decodes Base64 ‚Üí Hex ‚Üí Text
- Supports multiple decoding layers for deeply hidden flags

### ‚úÖ Gzip Decompression
- Detects and decompresses Gzip-encoded HTTP content
- Supports `Content-Encoding: gzip` payloads

### ‚úÖ DNS Layer Support
- Extracts flags from DNS queries and responses
- Useful for covert exfiltration or DNS tunneling-based CTF challenges

### ‚úÖ Enhanced Artifact Extraction
- Detects:
  - URLs (`http://`, `https://`)
  - JWT tokens
  - IP addresses
  - Email addresses
- Context-aware search with color-coded output

### ‚úÖ UX & Output Improvements
- Improved terminal banner
- Spinner-based loading animation
- Contextual summaries for each packet or stream match

---

## ‚öôÔ∏è Usage Examples

```bash
# Scan a single PCAP
python3 stichtted.py -f capture.pcap -l "HTB{.*?}"

# Scan a directory of PCAPs
python3 stichtted.py -d ./pcaps -l "CTF{.*?}"

# üõ†Ô∏è Dev Log ‚Äì STICHTTED v3.0

> Project by: **S4k3t**  
> Purpose: PCAP artifact extraction tool for CTFs, threat hunters & hackers

---

## ‚úÖ What's New in v3.0

- üîÑ **Full PyShark Integration**
  - Added support for `.pcapng` files
  - Deep inspection of HTTP headers and DNS queries
- üß† **Recursive Decoding**
  - Automatically decodes Base64 and hex payloads in multiple layers
- üõ∞Ô∏è **TCP Stream Reassembly**
  - Reconstructs full TCP conversations for richer analysis
- üîç **DNS Tunneling Detection**
  - Detects encoded flags and data in subdomains of DNS queries
- üß¨ **Source-Level Reporting**
  - Shows where each match was found (HTTP field, DNS layer, TCP stream)
- üìä **Match Count & Multi-Match Support**
  - Outputs total matches found, even across multiple sources

---

## üß™ Tech Stack

- `Python 3.8+`
- `Scapy` for low-level packet parsing
- `PyShark` for structured layer decoding (e.g., HTTP, DNS)
- Regex + recursive string processing

---

## üß© Known Limitations

- No live packet sniffing (only offline `.pcap/.pcapng`)
- Encrypted protocols (TLS/SSL) not decrypted
- No export to JSON/CSV (coming soon)

---

## üéØ Next Goals (v3.1+ Ideas)

- [ ] Export results to `.json` / `.csv`
- [ ] GUI/Web dashboard
- [ ] Threat feed correlation (VirusTotal, AbuseIPDB)
- [ ] FTP/SMTP/IRC protocol support
- [ ] Live packet capture mode (via PyShark live interface)

---

## ü§ò Dev Notes

- Focused on CTF practicality over bloated features
- All matches are shown with **source**, **context**, and **summary**
- Code optimized for fast scans and deep artifact inspection

---

## ‚ú® Quote

> *"Packets don‚Äôt lie. Stichtted just makes them talk."*

Today I started working on a basic Python CLI (command-line interface) calculator. The goal was to make something that can do simple math operations like:

‚úÖ Addition
‚úÖ Subtraction
‚úÖ Multiplication
‚úÖ Division

I used Python's input() function to take user input and then wrote functions for each operation. I also handled a small error ‚Äî dividing by zero ‚Äî to make it more reliable.

Here‚Äôs a screenshot of it running on my laptop (you can add one üì∏).

Next, I plan to add:

A GUI version using Tkinter

A history log for past calculations

Better error handling

Started refactoring to optimise for converting to an app or website in the future. This is done by extracting all functional functions away from CLI functions and making them only return data which is then used by CLI functions to display to the user. This means for the app/website, all I need to do is make a new UI function that just uses the logic of the functional function. This is a fairly long process so needs to be continued next time. So far I have finished the stats functions.

Started working on the Priority Scheduling algorithm today!

In this version, each process is assigned a priority number. The lower the number, the higher the priority. So instead of just going by arrival time like in FCFS, the CPU picks the process with the highest priority among the ones that have arrived.

It was fairly simple as I already had the FCFS algorithm, all I needed to do was sort the queue based on the priority given to it whenever a new process arrived.

Got the first come first serve (FCFS) algorithm working today!

The core of the algorithm is in, it loops through each millisecond of time, checks which processes have arrived, and runs them one by one in the order they showed up. Just like the name says: whoever comes first gets the CPU first, no interruptions.

One small bug I ran into was with the current process getting reset every loop, so each process was only running for 1ms before disappearing üòÖ. Turns out I was re-initializing currentProcess inside the loop and using an empty array instead of null, which made my condition checks fail. Once I moved it outside and properly tracked whether a process was still running, everything started falling into place.

There's not that much to devlog, frankly. This is a pretty straightforward library. I already knew how to make an npm library from my testing yesterday, although I did encounter some interesting issues on my way.

Markdown-it has a plugin system and some really old-looking docs, but they're understandable, particularly as I had an example already. The actual library part just took some minor edits and prettifying the whole thing.

For the library to appear on your GitHub repo's Packages page, you have to use GitHub's package registry, which is apparently a separate thing from npm. So you have to annoyingly log into two registries every time if you want to publish for both, unless you set up some custom CI, which is too much effort lol. Quite a dilemma.

I also found out that with TypeScript you can ship your files as an ESM module (newer), CommonJS or, with more setup - both. You need to setup some settings to make it compatible for both, which took me a little while and 9 whole public versions that should've totally been a single development one.

I'm making this for a future project of mine as well, gotta wait a little longer for that though.

Making the demo with Svelte was really easy, I know Svelte pretty well at this point and didn't encounter any issues there, but it was a little fun thing. Hosted it on Vercel because convenience, and downloading your own library feels pretty nice.

Next up is adding a custom class to the caption, which should be rather straightforward as well.

The terminal in GoLand on my Mac displays everything differently to apps like iTerm. On Windows, I can't even test my program directly in GoLand due to the terminal integrated in GoLand, because display errors occur there that can't be fixed.

Furthermore, I have to think carefully about how to integrate the data for the jpackage command into my program. Whether I do it dynamically via a JSON or another format or whether I integrate them all permanently into the program. Of course, everything has its own advantages and disadvantages. But I have to choose one of the two options.

Have a nice day and happy coding!

Since the last devlog I did a few different things:
- Made MIDI out port selectable through frontend

- Added first GUI Ideas using stitch.withgoogle.com (really cool tool, try it)

- Rebuild MIDI Output package to make it way more runtime efficient.
Up until now i had a function that could be called with an array with 127 elements (7bit used by midi) each containing a value of 0-172. The performance problem was: Each time the function was called (50 times a second) the selected midi output port was verified, opened, the values where send, the port was closed and the function returned nil or some error. 
It should be clear what the problem is right here.

The new package works way better and is more stable. I start my new output function using a go routine. The function than opens the selected midi port and iterates over a channel using a for range loop. This has the advantage that the code inside the loop only executes when there is something written to the channel. The send values (same array with 127 elements format is used) get than processed and send to the already opened midi channel. This has the advantage that the overhead of the package is only executed on initialization, and not on every update.

Today, I made a decision on the project finally. I've been debating it for awhile now. I couldn't decide whether or not writing a custom bootloader for this would be beneficial. I've decided it won't be, at least not right now, I've spent hours on page tables alone, and net to get moving. Limine offers an awesome protocol to use (it's own limine protocol) and I've switched to that. I was hesitant to because of multiboot, but found out about it's own which functions nicely through requests in your kernels binary. Pretty awesome, and today I got it booting with limine!

üõ† Devlog #1 ‚Äî Introducing Destrukture: Sharpen Your Frontend Skills with Realistic UI Challenges
Hey everyone!

We‚Äôre excited to finally introduce our latest side project: Destrukture üéâ
Destrukture is a platform built for frontend developers who want to level up their skills through practical UI and design challenges. Whether you're just starting out or looking to refine your craft, we‚Äôve created a space where you can push your boundaries and have fun doing it.

üß© What is Destrukture?
Destrukture helps you:

Find and solve new and unique design & user interface challenges

Practice building realistic, modern, and minimalistic UIs

Improve both your frontend coding and design interpretation skills

Each challenge is designed to be approachable yet rewarding ‚Äî no overly complex wireframes or unnecessary fluff. Just clean, smart design work that's fun to build.

üö¶ Difficulty Levels
We‚Äôve sorted our challenges into different difficulty tiers:
‚úÖ Beginner ‚Äì Perfect if you're learning HTML, CSS, and a bit of JavaScript
‚öôÔ∏è Intermediate ‚Äì A mix of layout logic and interactive features
üî• Advanced ‚Äì Complex interactions, animations, or UI architecture

This makes it easy to track your growth and pick challenges that match your current level.

üß† Why We Made This
We saw a gap in the frontend learning experience ‚Äî many developers jump from tutorials to frameworks without getting comfortable solving real UI problems on their own. We wanted a middle ground: a place where you can:

Practice building real-world interfaces

Develop a designer‚Äôs eye

Learn to work with constraints and clean design patterns

‚ú® What‚Äôs Next
More challenges (including dark mode and mobile-first ones)

Community submissions (submit your own solutions or designs!)

GitHub integration

A streak system to stay consistent

That‚Äôs it for now!
If you want to stay in the loop, follow us on [your socials here], or bookmark the site. And of course, try out a challenge ‚Äî we‚Äôd love to hear what you think!

Happy building,
The Destrukture Team

Vlog2 -

AIM - I am trying to create a web application which can automate the process of posting a tweet on latest news OR trending topics of twitter (trending hashtags) using AI.

Requirement -
1. We will need an API to fetch the latest news
2. We will need an API to fetch the trending topics from twitter.
3. We will need OpenAI / Gemini API to generate tweets.
4. Finally an API to automate the posting part from the website itself.

Progress - 
1. For fetching the latest news (breaking news) I have integrated the newsAPI which is publicly available. I am taking the location (geo-location) and category (in which user is interested) from the client side and passing this to newsAPI to get the latest news for that location in this category. I have also added support to fetch news of a specific time (so that we can get more and precise news).
2. For fetching the latest trending hashtags, I have used one of the RAPID APIs, it is also readily available. In this also I can pass the location.

I finally got Nim to cross compile to a UEFI executable! This is going to be great for my bootloader, the issue was, Nim was trying to use headers from my system folder to compile, and the headers were stdio.h and stdlib.h. Since these are not host-independent, I had to implement dummy headers that were placed in the include path instead that just prototyped the functions needed, even though they all have a dummy implementation.

Finally managed to iron out all the various bugs surrounding procedures in VTA. Turns out procedures need a lot of special casing because not only can they return multiple values, they also need any boxed inputs to remain unboxed - usually, boxed inputs are unboxed and passed into monomorphised blocks, which currently doesn't work with procedures - I would like to do procedure monomorphisation at some point but I need to figure out if it will be worth the trade off for code size. Not many lines changed for a long period of time but a lot of that was spent trying things out and then deleting them again.

So I've been thinking about how I might handle cycles and stuff and eventually decided to scrap the idea. 

Emulating the whole chip would be so much more complicated and most people using the module wouldn't even touch that stuff. I also decided not to reimplement everything in x86 assembly for portability reasons.

So, in theory the project should be over now. I will submit it after doing some testing

Worked on other curve fitting methods, including recursively splitting up curves to ensure they fit the line within a certain tolerance. Date: June 22, 2025
Duration: One day

I wanted to recreate one of the most nostalgic games ‚Äî the Snake Game ‚Äî in a way that's modern, responsive, and more polished than the typical clones. My goal was to learn more about canvas/grid logic and modular JS structure.

üîß What I Implemented:
A grid-based movement system using a 2D array logic

Snake tail growth upon eating apples

Death upon self-collision or hitting borders

Apple spawning at random grid positions

Score and High Score tracking with localStorage

Three difficulty levels affecting snake speed

A power-up system (gold apple every 5 apples)

Sound effects for movement, eat, and game over

Clean UI with restart and mute buttons

‚öôÔ∏è Technical Highlights:
Game logic controlled with setInterval (adjusted per difficulty)

Keyboard arrow keys for movement with input queue to prevent reverse errors

Audio toggle via JS + custom sound assets

Responsive layout using CSS Grid

Efficient snake-body tracking using arrays and shift/unshift logic

üöß Challenges Faced:
Preventing the snake from reversing directly into itself

Keeping power-ups from spawning on the snake's body

Managing game state (pause, restart, game over) cleanly

Handling fast movement on higher difficulties without frame skipping

üß† Lessons Learned:
Better understanding of timing/game loop logic

Modularizing game functions (reset, draw, update)

Enhanced canvas/grid visualization with clean CSS

How to manage localStorage for saving game state (score)

üèÅ Result:
A polished, fully working snake game that goes beyond the classic ‚Äî with difficulty control, golden apples, and a clean UI.
Built entirely with vanilla JavaScript and a creative mindset.

The program now adapts the language of the system. If the language does not exist, English is used. In Java, this can be done with so-called resource bundles. Since I don't know if there is such a thing in Go, I simply made my own.
Have a nice day and happy coding!

Date: June 23, 2025
Duration: One day
I wanted to create a simple yet engaging game that‚Äôs perfect for the browser.
A memory game was ideal ‚Äî it combines logic, animation, and user interaction.
The goal was to make it polished, responsive, and addictive to replay.

üîß What I Implemented
16-card grid with emoji pairs, shuffled every game

Click to flip: logic for revealing up to 2 cards at a time

Automatic reset of unmatched cards after a short delay

Score tracking: number of attempts to finish

Timer tracking: how long the user takes to win

Persistent high score saved locally

Clean restart logic

Sound effects for flipping, matching, and winning

Dark mode + modern minimalist UI using CSS Grid

üîä Sound System
flip.wav: plays when a card is flipped

match.wav: plays when a pair is matched

win.wav: plays when all pairs are matched

Mute toggle button to turn sound on/off without reloading

üöß What I Learned
How to manage state cleanly in simple games

Debouncing logic for clicks and timeouts

Making modular JS for better reusability

Real-time UI updates based on state

CSS transitions and hover effects

üß† Challenges Faced
Preventing multiple card flips while animations are active

Avoiding duplicate emoji placement

Syncing sound playback without lag

Resetting everything cleanly on restart

Built a Harry Potter-themed Memory Card Game in a single coding session as part of my journey to get comfortable with React. My main goal was to practice React‚Äôs core concepts‚Äîprops, components, state, and effects‚Äîby building something interactive and fun.

I chose a memory game because I used to enjoy making games before, and it‚Äôs a great way to reinforce logic and UI skills. The project utilizes the Harry Potter API to fetch character cards, and the game logic is entirely handled with React functional components and hooks. I focused on splitting the UI into reusable components (ScoreBoard, GameBoard, Card) and managing the game state with `useState` and `useEffect`.

This session helped me:
- Understand how props and state flow between components.
- Use effects for data fetching.
- Handle user interactions and dynamic UI updates.
- Practice responsive design and component styling.

Overall, I enjoyed making this‚Äîit was a great refresher on game logic and a solid learning experience with React.

‚è±Ô∏è 0‚Äì2h ‚Äì Project Setup & Planning

    Defined the concept: 4 quick, fun browser games in one portal.

    Selected tech stack: HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript, Canvas API.

    Created wireframes and notes for gameplay mechanics.

    Set up project structure and folders for each game.

‚è±Ô∏è 1h ‚Äì Game Prototyping (0,25h per game)

    Flying Chicken: Gravity, jumping, collision detection.

    Neon Runner: Track scrolling, obstacles, player movement.

    Cosmic Shooter: Shooting, enemies, power-ups.

    Puzzle Pop: Grid layout, flip/match logic.

‚è±Ô∏è 1,5h ‚Äì Core Game Logic & Controls

    Refined game loops using requestAnimationFrame.

    Implemented scoring, game-over states, and restart logic.

    Added input methods:

        Keyboard (PC)

        Touch (mobile)

        Mouse (where relevant)

‚è±Ô∏è 0,5h ‚Äì UI & Visuals

    Designed simple, clear graphics using shapes and colors.

    Styled the UI using CSS3 (buttons, text, overlays).

    Added animations and transitions for smoother experience.

    Ensured all interfaces scaled well on different screens.

‚è±Ô∏è 1h ‚Äì Responsiveness & Mobile Optimization

    Tested on various devices and resolutions.

    Tweaked canvas scaling and layout adjustments.

    Improved touch controls for smaller screens.

    Reduced lag and optimized rendering on mobile.


‚è±Ô∏è 0,5h ‚Äì Portal Page & Integration

    Built the main portal page with game preview tiles.

    Connected each game with consistent design and navigation.

    Implemented favicon and meta tags for mobile friendliness.
‚è±Ô∏è 1h ‚Äì Documentation

    Wrote README.md, DEVLOG.md, and usage notes.

    Prepared the repo for public release (clean code, comments).

    Added developer notes, future ideas, and contribution info.

üöß Challenges

    Scaling the canvas across a wide variety of screen sizes.

    Keeping code modular while using only Vanilla JS.

    Balancing minimalism with fun, playable design.

Features implemented:

Game Loop: Created a Game class managing the main game flow. Player movement via keyboard inputs (w, a, s, d) on a 10x10 grid map.

Map & Exploration: Randomly generated map with different cells: empty space, enemies (E), and treasures (T). Player position marked with P on the map display.

Combat System: Encounter random enemies with stats like HP, strength, defense. Simple turn-based combat with attack and flee options. Experience points (EXP) and gold rewards after defeating enemies.

Treasures & Inventory: Player can find treasures including gold and potions. Basic inventory system to hold and use items like health and strength potions.

Character Progression: Leveling system based on experience gained from battles. Character stats increase on level-up (HP, mana, strength, defense).

Save & Load: Save game state (player stats, position, map) to a JSON file. Load game from saved state.

I decided not to go for the mu setter first, but to make a more efficient state vector getter!

You see, if you call the position and velocity getter function separately, it ends up doing quite a few duplicate operations. Because of this, I'm creating more unchecked functions that take in multiple variables to allow redundant operations to be manually removed. And I'm using those unchecked functions in the state vector getter, so that API consumers can get the position and velocity more efficiently.

Small improvements:
1. I added command line argument parsing to the `dump-orbits` example binary.
2. I removed some unnecessarily-cached values in the Orbit struct. Although this led to a 7% performance regression in the worst case, that is only in the benchmarking environment where there is nothing else happening. In practical usage scenarios, though, the reduced struct size should increase the chance of cache hits and therefore reduce the amount of time the CPU needs to wait for RAM. And besides, it saves on a little memory.

I made expressions have different roles. Previously, both `1 + 2` and `1 (0‚äÉ‚ü®+‚ü©) 2` would work and come out to `3`, but the latter is very weird and means you can end up with expressions which were parsed differently based on the values of their tines at runtime. Now, only the former works, and if you want to call a function from an expression, you have to specify its arity with `‚ÇÄ subject`, `‚ÇÅ monad`, and `‚ÇÇ dyad`.

Hello!
This is the first devlog for my current project, which will eventually be a turn based strategy game similar to games like Advance Wars, X-COM, Roblox's Noobs in Combat, etc, but with cats!
I originally came up with the idea around a year ago, and started to develop it with a game engine called Microstudio (a web-based engine running off of HTML/Javascript but using a Lua-like programming language.
Eventually, it felt too limited to fully develop the game I envisioned in that engine, so I looked for alternatives. I settled on Unreal Engine over Unity due to the controversy surrounding it at the time, as well as the fact that it had blueprints (Since I don't know C# or C++ and figured blueprints would be easier).
I took a break from working on the project over this past school year since I've been busy, but I have started to slowly resume work on it. Progress will be pretty slow due to other things I have this summer, and I don't know if it will even be close to finished by the end of the summer, but we'll see.
You can find the original attempt at making a turn-based strategy game here: https://microstudio.dev/i/apinguen/tbsg/

Delving deeper into working with flutter, a few takeaways:
literally everything is a widget, every widget has a "build" function which must return a widget, ChangeNotifier enables other widgets to watch and use updates accordingly (all necessary variables and methods (NotifyListenters() at the end for methods) are stored in the myappstate, for now), Flutter Helper (ctrl + .) is very helpful in a lot tasks like extracting widgets (managing complexity), formatting a widget (wrapping it in another widget) 

misc: IconData, theme = Theme.of(context), mainAxisAlignment, mainAxisSize, Column, Row, SafeArea (prevent status bar from obstructing app view), Expanded (takes up all the space), NavigationRail (prevent navigation buttons from obscured by the status bar)

Minecraft Modding heavily relies on patches, and CommonLoader is no exception! One primary use of patches in CommonLoader are loading mods once Minecraft's resources are fully loaded, such as the GameRenderer. As CommonLoader is currently a JavaAgent, we have the ability to use the Instrumentation and Class File Transformer interfaces, which allow us to modify classes and their bytecode as they're loaded into memory by the JVM. CommonLoader has a fully annotation based API for injectables, so it's super easy to add your own.

# Dev-log 002 (English)
## Progress
I've modified the UI (styles.css) to have the Rose Pin√© theme and ended up using Flask to make a simple backend for login and a little intro to frontend data delivery.
## Ideas
1. Modify the backend so it doesn't use hardcoded variables and get the values from a `.env` file or a `settings.ini` file.
2. Make the dashboard load from the backend without needing to be a file written inside the folder and depending on what permissions the user has to run. Example: if I do not have a token / cookie that allows me to enter, right now what happens is that it loads for half a second the page and then redirects me to the login, I want it not to load the page but to load the login and if it could not enter a warning about why it could not enter and try again.
3. To make a database of users that can enter to a machine and that each one has its own permissions. that in a C++ structure would look like this:
```cpp
typedef bool Permissions[7];

struct User
{
	string name;
	string password_hash;
	Permissions permissions;
}
````
### Permissions thought:

- Shutdown
- Restart
- Lock
- Play/Pause
- Volume
- System Metrics
- Modify commands (Linux only)

3. Speaking of modifying commands, I would like that in linux environments the administrator user can choose which commands to use for each action, especially since linux is so customizable that it is basically impossible to know which packages are being used by users to control volume, and other things.

# 0.2.1!!!

Day 3: Today was ALL about PATHS!!!

**Features & Improvements:**

* üîÅ **Checksum-based diffing**: `upload` now uses MD5 hashes to determine whether remote files differ from local ones, reducing false positives from size-only checks.
* üóÇ **Directory operations**: Implemented creation/removal logic during upload using an abstracted `Op` enum and improved diff generation.
* ‚ùå **Exclusion support in `map`**: You can now add exclusions using `--excludes`, which updates the `flip.toml` mappings appropriately.
* üí¨ **CLI polish**:

  * Improved help messages and subcommand docs.
  * Introduced `--force-walkdir` flag to `upload` (stubbed with `unimplemented!()`).
  * Logging verbosity can be adjusted with `-v`, `-vv`, `-vvv`.

**Internal Changes:**

* üßπ Refactored diff passes into cleaner `prune`, `create`, and `update` stages.
* üîç Moved `join_as_relative` into a shared utility.
* üéØ Replaced `is_file`/`is_directory` helpers with direct checks to improve correctness and reduce misuse.
* üõ† Substantially cleaned up `main.rs`, including error handling, tracing setup, and command dispatch logic.

**Fixes:**

* Ensured logs are flushed before exiting on error.
* Reduced risk of desync in `.flippy_do_not_remove` sync logic.
```
feat: implement checksum-based remote diffing and clean up CLI

- Added MD5-based diffing to improve file sync accuracy
- Added `--force-walkdir` option to `upload` (not yet implemented)
- Added support for `--excludes` in `map` command
- Improved CLI help messages and structured logging
- Refactored tree diffing logic to support custom diff closures
- Removed false-positive size-only comparison and deprecated unused helpers
- Bumped version to 0.2.1
```

sooooo... I actually managed to simulate the entire season up until today and I got some pretty cool results! UAC is, IMO, rated much more fairly than OPR as their playoff performance was just lights out (finals had contributions of 270-300 points per match). LRG also drops a bit in EPA because spec/samp is not a sustainable playoff strategy :3 sorry Will. Overall quite happy with results, obviously not perfect but pretty close to what I was hoping for. I want to try and add in dynamic OPR calculations next to compare.
Overall prediction accuracy was at 70.63% for constant gain EPA, 70.76% for Kalman-based EPA (difference of 50 matches), and 77.26% for the cheating post-mortem OPR.

I saw a lot of people explaining their project in their first devlog so I'll start this one with an explanation. As the project description says, I'm creating a Minecraft mod that allows you to broadcast your singleplayer/multiplayer gameplay as a fake Minecraft server that allows people to join and spectate you as if they were watching a ReplayMod replay (they can't actually interact with anything). To do this, I'm capturing all the packets the host client receives from the server they're on (I'm starting with multiplayer first, singleplayer might be a bit different) and then storing and sending them to the spectator clients through a barebones Netty server.

Anyways, I spent a lot of time today rewriting Minecraft's networking code to work without a MinecraftServer object so that I can use it in my own Netty server. I think I'm basically done, but I've hit a roadblock with an EncoderException and NullPointerException that appears whenever I send a packet to the client. From looking at the logs, I suspect that the error comes from a problem with the Packet registry. I'm guessing the MinecraftServer class has a filled registry that I'm missing, but there's a lot of code to read over and some of it is a bit beyond me (I haven't used Java in quite a while). I'll try a bit longer to figure out what's happening and then call it a day.

# Upload System Overhaul + Mapping Refactor

## What Changed
NEW LOGO! It's even patented by OpenAI!

### BREAKING CHANGES (literally all of them)
* Replaced the old `Vec<Mapping>` system with a clean `Mappings` struct.

  * Each known mapping type (subghz, nfc, etc.) is now an optional `MappingEntry` with `include`/`exclude` lists.
* Introduced a `SyncFile` structure that gets written to Flipper as `/ext/.flippy_do_not_remove`.

  * This allows subsequent uploads to compute diffs quickly, skipping already-transferred files.
* `upload` is now a fully working command that computes a three-way diff, however it does not perform any operations yet, it just logs them
  * Uses `gix` to diff the local repo state
  * Falls back to a walking_diff (my personal algo) if sync info is missing
  * Applies diff ops conditionally (Copy, CreateDir, Remove) with user confirmation
* Improved UUID collision handling for repositories
* Upgraded `flipper-rpc` to use `transport-serial-optimized-large-stack-limit`, needed for large ass reads with some dirs
* Added significant internal diagnostics and tracing messages
* New flip.toml structure for mappings, I changed this to support a better diff algo.

# What Next?

* Persist remote tree metadata to reduce I/O overhead further
* Optimize `Copy` to batch file transfers
* Allow editing mappings from CLI

```
day 2: refactor(mapping): switch to typed mapping system, integrate sync file support

- Introduced new typed `Mappings` structure with explicit fields for each mapping type (e.g. subghz, nfc)
- Replaced vector of enum-based mappings with structured `MappingEntry` objects
- Updated `.gitignore` to include `/f0` temporary files
- Upgraded `flipper-rpc` to 0.6.3 with `large-stack-limit` transport feature
- Switched upload flow to rely on a persistent sync file for fast diffing
- Implemented file transfer ops as diff ops: Copy, CreateDir, Remove
- Improved path handling and structured remote directory interactions
- Prevented duplicate repositories by checking both UUID and name
- Added fallback logic for first-time uploads without sync metadata
```

The program:

Prompts the user to enter:

Number of days

Number of hours

Number of minutes

Number of seconds

Converts each time unit into seconds:

1 day = 86400 seconds

1 hour = 3600 seconds

1 minute = 60 seconds

Adds them up to calculate the total time in seconds.

Outputs the total seconds.

I Built an Anonymous Social Feed in Python (No Login. Just Vibes.)



Started working on a small social media experiment where anyone can post whatever they want ‚Äî text or photos ‚Äî completely anonymously. No logins, no usernames, no likes, no followers ‚Äî just vibes. The idea is to create a chill space where people can say things or share moments without the pressure of having an account.

In app.py, I set up the Flask server, connected it to an SQLite database, and created routes for viewing and submitting posts. I added image upload support with file validation, input cleaning, and checks to prevent empty posts. Flash messages throw sass if users try to post nothing.

üîó Install Plugins Directly from the Dashboard!

Great news: NetTool now supports installing plugins directly through its web UI, using GitHub as the plugin source!
üõ†Ô∏è How It Works

    Browse available plugins in the Plugins section of the dashboard.

    Select a plugin from GitHub.

    Click Install ‚Äî NetTool fetches, builds, and activates it automatically.

üéØ Why This Is a Game-Changer

    Seamless UX: No need to clone repos, build code locally, or restart the app.

    One-click activation: Discover and enable functionality without touching the command line.

    GitHub-powered: Always fetch the latest version of your favorite plugins.

Did a touch of redesigning my flight controller configurator app, but mainly I made **huge** progress with my ultrasonic sensor!!!


I have been putting off trying to improve timing logic for it (and tried giving more priority, which just slowed down everything), but finally programmed a driver using the *PIO* feature on Raspberry Pi Picos. This beautiful Programmable Input Output (PIO) feature basically allows me to write custom assembly code to handle my ultrasonic sensor that runs on a **dedicated onboard core designed for I/O**. The program in the image is the assembly implementation, which happens to be my first successful PIO program!!


With my new PIO ultrasonic sensor driver, I get *great performance/speed/reliability*, and the readings from the sensor are the most stable I've seen IN MY LIFE (when standing still, the registered distance basically *does not change*).

2025-06-23 update 2:
first i decided to add a simple feature that's needed for the notebook: raw data output. all in all the command was like 20 lines of additional code and plus copilot pretty much autocompleted 60% of it.

after that though i noticed when bundling that there were two warnings: an unnecessary import and circular dependencies. i knew what was causing the circular dependency issue, but the import was new to me, eslint hadn't raised any warnings. i found out it was because i used an import only for a type, and ended up importing the whole function :p

onto the circular dependency issue, i had been meaning to do it but one of the functions, tempClone, was a really thin wrapper around git.clone that was better off being inlined in the *one* function that consumes it. i inlined the function and.. voila! no more circular dependency issues. i ran the test suite for the outside function and it still passed, so all good there. (that being said, i really should add more tests... i only have five... ill probably work on that next.)

after that, i wandered online and then decided to wire up two plugins to eslint and prettier. one was an import sorting plugin from trivago (!!) and the other reworked confusing conditionals. i'm not sure if this exists but my dream plugin would refactor/flatten nested if-else statements... copilot usually works fine though.

i knew that i wanted `node:` imports first, then unscoped packages, then scoped, then relative imports. i'd been *kinda* following that, but very loosely, so the former plugin would make things a lot nicer. unfortunately the plugin is configured with regexes, which *suuuuck* to do by hand so i used copilot :pp took a few tries but it got there!

another thing that had broke with the monorepo refactor was eslint and prettier ignore cases.. so i cleaned up after those as well. i wrote a recursive .gitignore finder in my eslint config (god what a day to be in javascript land) and added more stuff to the root .gitignore. yknow what life would probably be a lot easier if i just made one gitignore file... but oh well, time wasted is time wasted, we learn from our mistakes.

i don't have the energy left in me to work on other features, since i'll be using observable plot for the notebook, which means i should probably switch over chart creation to that in the CLI... basically a lot of the more important work is boring stuff and not features. might write unit tests to end off the day because even *that's* less boring to me.

Date: June 24, 2025
Duration: One day

Design Vision:
I started the project with a vision for minimalism blended with futuristic aesthetics ‚Äî inspired by glassmorphism, soft UI shadows, and smooth scrolling.
I didn‚Äôt use Figma or external UI tools ‚Äî I coded directly in the browser using my own intuition and visual sense.

HTML Structure:
I structured the page using semantic HTML5 tags with clear sections: intro, about, expertise, timeline, and contact. Navigation was crafted for both desktop and mobile from scratch.

 CSS Styling:
I implemented a clean, glassy look using:

backdrop-filter for blur effects

box-shadow for glowing borders

Responsive grid and flex layouts

Media queries for screens < 900px

Reusable variables for theme colors

Responsiveness:
One of the biggest priorities was ensuring full compatibility across screen sizes. I built a mobile burger menu that transforms into a vertical nav with animation.

JavaScript & jQuery:
I used vanilla JavaScript and some jQuery for:

Smooth scrolling to anchors

Animated preloader

Toggling mobile menu

Scroll-triggered animations

Challenges Faced
Getting the backdrop-filter to look consistent on different browsers.

Making the navigation intuitive on mobile while keeping it animated.

Keeping everything in sync with the theme (neon blue on dark).

Result
A fast, elegant, and fully responsive portfolio template that can be reused or customized for future projects or freelance clients.

Reflection
Building Luther in one focused day was both a challenge and a creative release. I relied solely on code (no page builders or UI kits), which pushed me to sharpen my eye for spacing, motion, and responsiveness.

This project helped reinforce my frontend skills and gave me a beautiful template to showcase to others ‚Äî all hand-built from scratch.

Date: June 24, 2025
Duration: One day

Overview:
This project is a fully responsive and animated personal portfolio landing page, crafted entirely within a single day. It was built using HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and jQuery, with a strong focus on modern design aesthetics, accessibility, and performance.

Objectives:
To create a sleek, interactive landing page that reflects my personal brand as a front-end developer.

To challenge myself by delivering a complete, polished UI/UX experience within 24 hours.

Key Features:
üé¨ Fullscreen Background Video: Adds dynamic visual appeal.

üì± Mobile-Friendly Design: Responsive layout with a burger menu for smaller screens.

üß≠ Smooth Navigation: Animated scrolling and active link indicators.

üëã Hero Section: Includes a brief intro, role, and CTA buttons (e.g., "Download CV").

üåê Social Links: Icons for GitHub, LinkedIn, Twitter, and YouTube.

üßÆ Statistics Footer: Projects completed, experience years, and client count.

üåà UI Enhancements: Hover animations, blurred background effects, and clean typography.

Technologies Used:
HTML5

CSS3

JavaScript 

Font Awesome for icons

Challenges:
Working under a 24-hour limit was both intense and rewarding. The biggest challenge was maintaining code quality and visual polish under time pressure ‚Äî especially ensuring responsive behavior across devices.


Outcome:
A professional-grade portfolio page that can be easily reused or expanded into a full personal website. It not only demonstrates my technical abilities but also my design sense and time management under pressure.

Today was really tough. After spending another hour or so trying to fix the errors, I found out that for some reason directly joining the server instead of pinging for its status doesn't cause the error. So, I went to work trying to send the raw packet data through my Netty channel. Since during the setup of the Netty server there were a lot of things in the channel pipeline that messed up my raw bytes, I had to strip out most of the handlers inside the pipeline. I eventually got the raw bytes through (This took way too long). I then began piping the captured packets to the client through the channel, but I was met with another roadblock. This time the spectating client errors out with a DecoderException, stating that it failed to decode the Login (Play) packet.

On a separate note I've reworked the SpectatorServer and ClientChannelMixin so that the packet sniffer doesn't activate for my emulated server (I don't know why I didn't realize I needed to do this earlier)

AIM
To build a full-stack application that generates AI-powered tweets using verified news articles and trending Twitter topics. The tweets are creative, tone-aware, and based on real-time data.
Users can register, log in, and generate custom tweet content based on:
Recent news (via News API)
Trending Twitter topics (via RapidAPI)
Selected tone, stance, and category

PROGRESS -
1. Server Side:
> OTP-Based Email Verification System
Implemented OTP flow using Google SMTP.
OTP expires after 5 minutes.
Resends OTP if expired (instead of blocking the user).

> Role-Based Access Middleware
Middleware to restrict endpoints based on user roles (admin/user).
Protected sensitive routes using authenticate and authorize.

2.Client-Side:
> React Project Setup
Initialized project using create-react-app.

> Routing and Pages
Setup of main routes using react-router-dom:
/ (Landing)
/login
/register
/verify-otp
/dashboard

> Authentication Flow
Register and Login pages with Axios integration to the backend.
After register, redirected to OTP verification.
Token saved to localStorage.
Axios interceptor attached to add Authorization header.

> Protected Routes
/dashboard protected using ProtectedRoute component.
Redirects to login if token is missing or expired (verified using jwt-decode).
Login/Register redirect to dashboard if already authenticated.

> Dashboard Functionality
UI to select tone, category, stance, and location.
Buttons to trigger:
"Generate Tweet from News"
"Generate Tweet from Twitter Trends"
API calls made and results displayed in cards, including tweet text and placeholder image.

So, What's New?

- Chain Reactions: Inspired by games like Candy Crush, we've added new colored blocks that spawn in clusters. Breaking a block in a group of three or more now triggers a satisfying chain reaction, clearing the entire cluster!

- New Animations & Feedback: To make the game feel more alive, I have also added dust and particle effects for breaking blocks, crack textures for multi-hit "Special Blocks", and a full respawn animation with invincibility frames to give players a fair chance after losing a life (although the physics and stuff still need tweaking since it can sometimes be unfair to players).

- UI Overhaul: I've updated the title, pause and death screens, including Graphics Settings where you can toggle performance-intensive effects like bloom and particles.

The last couple devlogs have been slow, but all of the trying and failing there has compounded in the last hour and a half. I've gotten both the lexer and logarithms working.
First, the lexer. Turns out that beyond some precision problems in my number recognition, it was mostly bug-free. I'm sure something will come up later, but it's working well enough now for me to continue.
Next, logarithms. I spent a little while learning about how they actually work; much less superficially than I thought I knew them before. My implementation uses a series to calculate natural logarithms. I then use this to calculate log base 2, which takes advantage of the fact that IEEE-754 floating point is basically just scientific notation to make it ridiculously fast. Finally, I can trivially calculate logs of any base using the identity log base a (x) = log base b (x) / log base b (a). My implementation is not only precise, but it's more than fast enough for my needs.

Woah! 0.8.0! (wern't we just at 0.6.x?? Nevermind, I put alot of updates out lol)

This fixes a *few* things. Larger files are now supported by fs-write, using the unorthodox "send a ping every so and so" strategy taken from qFlipper to keep the connection alive.

You can now create_dir while the dir already exists, this just does nothing now.
You can now extract flipper-side .tgz to extract files, used in flippy to read firmware updates and send them faster.

MPSC Channels now take Options, so you dont HAVE to track progress when fs-progress-mpsc is enabled.

Bout it!

Most of these updates relate to firmware in flippy.

**CHANGELOG**
## 0.8.0

### BREAKING CHANGES

- **mpsc** When MPSC is enabled, make tx an Option.

### Fixed

- **fs-write** Taken from qFlipper, when writing large files, insert a ping
  every once and a while to keep the connection alive.

## 0.7.1

- **fs-tar-extract** Implements the Tar Extraction API, useful for firmware
  updates.

## 0.7.0

### BREAKING CHANGES

- **fs-createdir** No longer errors if the directory already exists.

Today I finally finished the model loader (fixed all of the bugs). I largely spent most of the time debugging the Mesh class, where glDrawElements wasn't working - the app ran fine, but nothing was displayed and even RenderDoc failed to capture it. It turned out that the Mesh destructor was being called when it was copied into Model::m_meshes after it was generated, where glDeleteVertexArrays was being called, meaning the vertex array was invalid (long story short, c++ is complicated). But model rendering works now at least!

Since I'm doing this project entirely client side, it's been a challenge to attempt to get the other file formats working. Although JPEG, PNG, and WebP are done (almost) entirely by canvas, ICO took longer to make, but I eventually figured out that it is possible to convert a PNG to ICO and still get it to work via an external NPM library. These aren't entirely complete yet, especially ICO as it resizes the image to 256x256, but it's a good starting point.

üõ† Devlog #2 ‚Äî Dashboards, Protection & Publishing: Destrukture Evolves
Hey builders üëã

We‚Äôre back with Devlog #2, and this update brings a huge boost to how you interact with Destrukture. From content creation to UI challenge management ‚Äî we‚Äôve been working on giving you more control, structure, and security in the experience.

Let‚Äôs break it down üëá

üß± Two Dashboards. Two Roles.
We‚Äôve introduced two purpose-driven dashboards:

1. ‚úçÔ∏è Articles Dashboard
This is your space to share thoughts, tips, tutorials, or mini-blogs.

Create and post articles in a clean, focused interface

Instant publishing to the /articles feed

Easily delete old posts

Built with clean, modern UI principles

2. üéØ Challenges Dashboard
Built for creators who want to contribute UI challenges to the community.

Submit new challenges with a title, description, tags, image, and optional link

All submissions appear on the public /challenges page

Supports deletion for cleanup and iteration

Simple and minimal ‚Äî just the essentials

This dual setup gives both writers and builders a space to contribute meaningfully.

üîê Dashboard Password Protection
To keep Destrukture curated and focused, we‚Äôve added password protection to both dashboards.

Only authenticated users can post or delete content ‚Äî ensuring quality and reducing noise.

You‚Äôll see a password screen before accessing either dashboard, and once authenticated, you‚Äôre in. Simple as that.

üîß Under the Hood: Smarter Routes and Storage
We‚Äôve added full backend support to make this all function smoothly:

‚úÖ POST, GET, and DELETE operations for both articles and challenges

‚úÖ Challenges support tags (as arrays), cover images, optional external links

‚úÖ All data is stored and fetched using robust Prisma models

‚úÖ Clean deletion logic for keeping things tidy

Everything is built to scale and stays true to the goal: realistic challenges, clean code.

‚ú® What‚Äôs Coming Next
Here‚Äôs a peek at what we‚Äôre working on next:

GitHub login and user profiles

Community challenge submissions

Challenge filtering by difficulty or tags

Weekly challenge system + streaks

Live previews of UI challenges

üèÅ Try It Now
If you‚Äôve been waiting to create, now‚Äôs the time:

Post your own design challenges

Share a learning or tip via articles

Explore what others are building

Destrukture is quickly evolving into a focused, fun playground for frontend developers ‚Äî and we can‚Äôt wait to see what you create here.

Build on,
‚Äì The Destrukture Team

I finally wrote a README for my project.

Introduction
I decided to create InspectMe ‚Äì an interactive educational game designed to help beginners learn HTML, CSS, and DOM manipulation. The goal is to combine enjoyable gameplay with practical frontend skills, especially working with CSS selectors and basic element operations.

What‚Äôs planned so far?
Game mechanics: The player will complete tasks like finding and modifying elements on the page (e.g., click an element with a certain class, change an element‚Äôs text, add a class, etc.).

Game modes: Classic, timed, chaos (random selectors), and creative (level editor).

UI: Inspired by developer tools (DevTools) with a dark theme and monospace font.

Technologies: Vanilla JS / React (to be decided), HTML, CSS.

First steps
Designed the app structure and main components:

Task panel / instructions

Game area with interactive HTML elements

Validation system to check correctness of user actions

Scoring and feedback system

Built a prototype for a simple task: ‚ÄúClick the element with class .highlight.‚Äù The page shows several elements; the user clicks, and the app verifies the correctness.

Started working on the UI, aiming for a DevTools-like style: dark background, neon blue accents, monospace font.

Created a moodboard to define the visual style and branding ‚Äî focusing on black and neon blue terminal aesthetics.

Next steps
Expand the task list and validation methods (different types of interactions)

Add timed mode and level progression system

Design scoring and progress bars

Improve responsiveness and user experience

Set up GitHub repository with documentation and starter code

As part of the project to deploy Raspberry Pi devices for digital signage, I have completed the following key steps:

Raspberry Pi Setup
Installed the appropriate operating system (e.g., Raspberry Pi OS) on multiple Raspberry Pi units.

Connected each device to display screens via HDMI, ensuring resolution and display settings were properly configured.

Network Configuration
Set up stable Wi-Fi connections on all devices to enable remote access.

Configured SSH and VNC for easier monitoring, file transfers, and remote updates.

Python Environment
Installed and configured essential Python libraries required for media display and control (e.g., pygame, omxplayer-wrapper, or similar).

Set up a virtual environment for organized script management.

Basic Display Script
Developed a Python script that loops through image and video files from a designated folder.

Ensured smooth transitions and reliable media playback without manual intervention.

Initial Automation
Wrote automation scripts using both Python and PHP to:

Automatically detect new content in a local folder.

Replace or update display files based on time or folder changes.

Push updates to the Raspberry Pi or display them dynamically.

Testing
Conducted initial testing on a single screen setup to verify:

Correct boot-up behavior.

Media playback loop functionality.

Automated content updates.

Confirmed that both the display and update automation work as intended in a real-world scenario.

Syslog Integration (Completed Previously)
Completed syslog configuration and integration for centralized logging.

Set up log forwarding from Raspberry Pi devices to a syslog server for easier monitoring and diagnostics.

2025-06-25 update 2:
a lot of updates for this update since SoM was down!

first off, i improved the chart styling. i first tried just directly importing the styling from observable framework by building the `notebooks` package, but that led to some string parsing errors and figured that it was likely not worth the time doing that. however, i asked copilot to make some quick styling and it's an improvement! i ended up making a helper function that wraps the plot outer HTML in its own HTML, which would also help for maintainability if i want to change default styling across all functions later down the line.

the next things are a few small improvements. i first made it so that the title's `top {x}` label would follow the number of authors *actually* displayed, which accounts for small repos like `octocat/Hello-World`. then, i configured plot to not show chart labels for nonintegers, which again, coves the `octocat/Hello-World` edge case. finally, i added a `--max` flag that makes the max authors configurable, which is demonstrated in this chart!

there are a few small things i want to work on next, including more styling and flags, but i really want to get to finishing `commit-activity` and decide on next major features to implement.

on a side note, yesterday i was looking through the isomorphic-git docs more and they don't have a `git blame` feature... i'll have to research more about git and either implement it upstream or have a naive implementation in my project. one of the features i have planned needs that command.

OK, WOW. I have never went so deep into debugging, but today I did, there were SO MANY BUGS, one bug after the other, just to add my chatbot widget. I started out just coding the chatbot widget, got the backend working, but then somehow the whole background image for the page went away and I could not see anything, after that was eventually fixed there were more 404 errors, the chatbot kept not responding and then I had to restructure where the code folders were, put new folders, change build commands in Vercel, leaked my API key once(yeah um) and after all that, my weather api key just was not working so I tried so many debugging steps that just led me down an endless path, or so I thought cause I eventually made it work so Vercel could detect it, and it worked(I originally thought it just was not being pushed to Github for some reason but it was).
